title: Charles Dickens Museum
inscription: Dickens rented this Georgian terraced house from 25 March 1837 to December 1839. It was his first substantial home in London.
address: 48 Doughty Street, King’s Cross, Camden WC1N 2LX

title: House in Town
inscription: Dickens moved with his growing family to this house in 1839 and lived there until 1851.

title: Tavistock House
inscription: Dickens leased this large house from 1851 to 1860.

title: Furnival’s Inn
inscription: As a young journalist Dickens rented chambers in Furnival’s Inn between December 1834 and early 1837. The Inn was demolished in 1897; a brown plaque on the Prudential Building marks the spot.

title: Marshalsea Prison
inscription: In February 1824 Dickens’s father John was imprisoned for debt in the Marshalsea. Twelve‑year‑old Charles lodged first in Camden and then on Lant Street (SE1) near the prison.

title: Little Dorrit’s Church
inscription: Dickens first knew this church in 1824 when his father was in the nearby Marshalsea prison. It later appeared in his novel Little Dorrit.
address: St George the Martyr Church, Borough High Street SE1 1JA

title: Warren’s Blacking Factory
inscription: At age 12 (from 1824–1825) Dickens worked here labeling pots of blacking after his father’s imprisonment.

title: Bob Fagin
inscription: During his father’s imprisonment, Dickens lodged in a house on Lant Street belonging to the vestry clerk of St George’s Church.

title: City Pickwick Club
inscription: This 18th‑century chop house is mentioned over 20 times in The Pickwick Papers and Dickens frequently drank and dined here. CAMRA records state that the top floor contains “Dickens Rooms” because the writer lived here for a time.

title: Ye Olde Cheshire Cheese
inscription: A rebuilt 17th‑century tavern; Dickens was a regular patron.

title: The Daily News
inscription: Fleet Street was London’s journalism hub. In January 1846 Dickens launched and briefly edited The Daily News at No. 92 Fleet Street.

title: Household Words
inscription: In 1850 Dickens rented offices here for his weekly journal Household Words.
address: 16 Wellington Street North, Covent Garden WC2E

title: All the Year Round
inscription: From 1859 Dickens published All the Year Round, the successor to Household Words, from this address.
address: 26 Wellington Street North, Covent Garden WC2E

title: Garrick Club
inscription: The exclusive theatrical club, founded in 1831, counted Dickens among its famous 19th‑century members. He socialised with actors and fellow writers here.

title: The Old Curiosity Shop
inscription: A timber‑framed building near Lincoln’s Inn Fields. In the 1880s a shop owner placed the words “The Old Curiosity Shop – Immortalised by Charles Dickens” on the facade to attract trade.

title: Home of the Plornish family
inscription: This cobbled courtyard in Holborn inspired the home of the Plornish family in Little Dorrit. Dickens described it as a place of decayed grandeur inhabited by poor families.

title: Reading Room
inscription: The iconic circular Reading Room opened in 1857 and served as a scholarly hub for Victorian writers. A Wikiversity list of readers includes Charles Dickens among its notable users.

title: The Good Mixer
inscription:
You’re standing outside one of the unlikeliest landmarks in British music history.

Right here, at this corner pub, a guitarist walks in. At the bar he meets his chart rival. There’s a bit of small talk, a bit of beer, and then supposedly, one legendary line:

“Nice music,” he says. “Shit clothes.”

It’s the kind of off-hand insult that could have been forgotten in five minutes – except this is the 1990s, the bands are Blur and Oasis, and the music press is desperate for a feud. Whether it happened exactly that way or not, this little pub gets written into the creation myth of Britpop.

And you’re standing right outside it.
lead_subject_bio:
Look around you – present day vs past

Take a moment to look up at the pub itself.
The blue frontage, the modest sign, the corner windows. It does not look like a rock museum. It looks like… a pub. A proper London boozer.

Now turn your head along Inverness Street, towards the market stalls and food places. A few steps away is the tourist river of Camden High Street, with its street art, vintage shops and tattoo studios.

It’s hard to imagine now, but this corner wasn’t always drenched in band T-shirts and bucket hats. Before the gossip, before the record deals, before the Noel-and-Graham legends, this spot had a very different story.

From bomb site to “good mixer”

Rewind to the Second World War. The pub that originally stood on this corner was called The Cricketers. During the Blitz, it was destroyed by bombing. For a while, this was just another scar in a battered city.

In the 1950s, the new building goes up – the one you’re looking at now. A fresh post-war pub for a working-class neighbourhood. Builders, market traders, bus drivers, bikers: this is their place.

And then there’s the name.

Local legend says that while they were building the pub, the contractors somehow left a cement mixer in the cellar. Rather than haul it out, they just bricked around it. The new place, people say, was christened in its honour: The Good Mixer.

Is that literally true? Hard to prove. It has all the hallmarks of a story polished over many retellings. But it fits the character of the place: a bit rough around the edges, practical, not taking itself too seriously.

For decades, the Good Mixer is just that – a fairly ordinary Camden boozer. Smoky, cheap, a little sketchy at times. No one is queuing up to take selfies outside.

Then the 1990s arrive… and Camden changes gear.

Camden goes Britpop

Fast-forward to the early–mid ’90s. Guitar bands are everywhere. The music press needs a scene to hang a story on, and Camden obliges.

Venues and pubs around here become a network of hangouts: the Laurel Tree, the Falcon, the Dublin Castle… and the Good Mixer, this unglamorous corner bar, ends up as the unofficial common room.

Picture the scene: it’s a weeknight in 1995.
You push open that door in front of you. Cigarette smoke hangs under the low ceiling. The jukebox is churning out something jangly and loud. By the pool table, there’s a band you’ve half-heard of. Next week they’ll be on the cover of NME.

Blur drink here. So do Oasis, at least sometimes. Pulp roll through. Elastica. Supergrass. Menswe@r. A&R people, journalists, hangers-on – everyone orbiting the same sticky tables.

The Camden myth is that if you stood at this bar for long enough in the mid-90s, you’d end up next to somebody famous… or somebody who was utterly convinced they were about to be.

Feuds, deals and scene gossip

And this is where our insult fits in.

One night, Oasis’s Noel Gallagher encounters Blur’s Graham Coxon at the bar. Noel, never exactly shy, is supposed to have greeted him with: “Nice music, shit clothes.”

That line – whether it’s perfectly accurate or slightly polished with hindsight – is too good for the tabloids and the music papers to resist. They’re already banging on about a north–south turf war: working-class Manchester vs art-school London. Oasis vs Blur. The Good Mixer suddenly finds itself cast as a tiny stage in a very loud soap opera.

But this place is more than just a punchline factory.

Over there, imagine a corner table where contracts are being slid across the sticky wood. Elastica are said to have agreed a record deal in here. Menswe@r become so closely associated with the pub and its club nights that they turn into a walking advert for Camden cool.

For some, this world is thrilling – a blur of free drinks, late nights and sudden acclaim. For others, especially some of the women moving in and out of these same doors, it can be cliquey and exhausting: looks judged as much as songs; whispers spread as fast as singles.

Still, the Good Mixer keeps doing what it’s always done: serving pints and providing somewhere to sit while careers rise, fall and combust around it.

Look around you – layering the 90s over now

Take another look at the building in front of you.

Squint a little and mentally swap out today’s tourists for 1990s haircuts and big trainers. Imagine the door banging open, a blast of guitar from the jukebox, a cloud of smoke rolling out onto the pavement.

Inside, the pool table is crowded with hopefuls and has-beens. At the bar, journalists are scribbling in notebooks, pretending not to stare. Somebody is loudly predicting that their new single is going to “change everything”.

Camden in this era isn’t just a place; it’s a rumour mill. And the Good Mixer is one of its loudest grinding wheels.

From Britpop lads to Amy’s Camden

Eventually, Britpop burns itself out. The haircuts change, the fashions move on, the bands either implode or become “heritage”.

But the Good Mixer doesn’t vanish with the headlines.

In the 2000s, another chapter opens. Amy Winehouse makes Camden her patch, and this pub becomes one of the places she drops into – along with a few other locals around here. There are stories of her playing pool, chatting to regulars, just being a neighbour rather than a global name.

Same bar stools, different soundtrack. Instead of “Girls and Boys” or “Common People”, you can imagine Back to Black echoing somewhere in the background.

Years later, when filmmakers recreate Amy’s life for the screen, the Good Mixer shows up again as a location – the real pub playing itself in a story about the real pub. By then, people are coming here not just to drink, but to chase their own version of the myth.

Survival in a changing Camden

Like many Camden pubs and venues, the Good Mixer hasn’t had an easy ride. At one point there are serious rumours it’ll be shuttered and turned into flats. For a while it does close, and locals worry it’s gone for good.

But it reopens under new management, promising to stay what it’s always fundamentally been: a music-friendly, slightly scruffy, unpretentious boozer. No reclaimed-wood wine wall. No twelve-page cocktail list. Just a stage for small bands, a bar, and a lot of history soaked into the floorboards.

Look ahead – and to the next stop

So, one last look around you.

You’re standing at a pretty ordinary junction: a blue-fronted pub, market stalls behind you, tourists drifting towards Camden Lock. But layered over what you see are all the earlier versions of this same corner:

A wartime bomb site.
A 1950s working men’s pub.
A 1990s rumour factory where a daft insult becomes national news.
A neighbourhood bar where Amy Winehouse lines up a shot on the pool table.

In a city where venues can disappear almost overnight, the Good Mixer is still here, quietly mixing its history with whatever comes next.

From here, you might carry on to other Britpop haunts – the former home of Blow Up at the old Laurel Tree site, or the Dublin Castle – to follow the rest of that guitar-band story. Or you could head towards the Stables Market and find the bronze statue of Amy Winehouse, another piece of Camden’s musical memory cast in metal.

But when you pass this corner again, you’ll know: it’s not just a pub. It’s where a bomb site became a boozer, a boozer became a Britpop HQ, and a throwaway comment at the bar turned into pop-culture folklore.

title: The Laurel Tree
inscription:
You’re standing on a pretty ordinary Camden corner. Brick building, tall windows, the ghost of pub signage around the ground floor. If you didn’t know better, you’d just walk past it on your way to the markets or the tube.

But for a few years in the 1990s, the small upstairs room above your head was being called “the club that changed the world.”

Welcome to 113 Bayham Street – once The Laurel Tree. If Britpop had a living room, this might well have been it.
lead_subject_bio:
Look around you for a moment.
Notice the shape of the building: that chamfered corner, the tall Victorian windows, the proportions of a classic London pub. For most of its life, that’s all this place was – a straightforward neighbourhood boozer. Landlord downstairs, family and staff living above, regulars drifting in after a shift. Mid-century photos show cheerful drinkers posed in front of a charabanc parked outside, ready for a pub outing. Camden life, long before anyone had heard of Britpop.

For more than a hundred years, nothing about the Laurel Tree suggested it was destined for music history. No stage, no famous gigs, no legendary nights. Just darts, pints, gossip. The kind of place that rarely makes it into guidebooks.

Its moment doesn’t arrive until the early 1990s – and it starts, as these things often do, with one slightly irritated person and a half-baked idea.

In this case, the irritated person is Paul Tunkin, a DJ and promoter from Southend. It’s 1993. Grunge is everywhere: baggy jeans, lumberjack shirts, songs about alienation sung through curtains of hair. If you happen to love sharp suits and 60s records, it can all feel a bit… droopy.

Tunkin wants the opposite. He wants energy. Hooks. Melody. Style. He loves 1960s British pop, soul, punk, obscure soundtrack tunes – anything that feels like it’s in love with life rather than fed up with it. He gives this idea a tongue-in-cheek name: “Orgasmic Pop.”

All he needs now is a room.

The Laurel Tree’s upstairs function room isn’t glamorous, but it’s available and cheap. Low ceiling, small bar, not much in the way of decor. It’s the kind of space usually hired for 21st birthdays and darts prize-givings.

In October 1993, Tunkin hauls in his records and a sound system and launches a weekly club night he calls Blow Up.

On that first night, there’s no neon sign announcing history in the making. Just a mix of locals, friends from Southend and a few curious Camden strays climbing the stairs, not quite sure what they’re in for.

What they get is a shock to the system.

Imagine yourself queuing for Blow Up in, say, 1994.

Look around you again, but this time roll the street back thirty years in your mind. The pavements are busier. There’s a line snaking along Bayham Street, kids in neat suits and parkas, girls in 60s-style dresses and eyeliner you can almost see from here. Above you, those upstairs windows are steamed up, the glass rattling slightly with bass.

You climb the narrow staircase. Cigarette smoke hits you first. Then the heat. Then the sound.

Inside, the room is packed. There’s no cool detachment here – people are actually dancing. On the decks, Tunkin is pinballing between The Kinks, Small Faces, northern soul stompers, punk records by Buzzcocks, odd bits of spy-movie soundtrack, and the occasional weird easy-listening track thrown in for a laugh. And threading through it all are new British guitar bands – rough demos and early singles that, in this setting, suddenly make perfect sense.

The crowd looks like a living collage: mods, indie kids, fashion students, people who’ve clearly raided their parents’ wardrobes. Where other clubs at the time lean into slouchy grunge, Blow Up feels like a costume party where everyone’s in on the joke.

If you could somehow freeze the room and start zooming in on faces, you’d spot a few that will end up on magazine covers. Members of Blur, Pulp, Suede, Elastica, Buzzcocks, The Jesus and Mary Chain, riot-grrrl bands like Huggy Bear – they all pass through here at one time or another. Some DJ. Some play live. Many just drink, flirt, watch the crowd, and steal ideas.

Local lore even says that Coldplay played their first ever gig at The Laurel Tree. Whether or not that’s strictly true, it’s exactly the kind of story that belongs to a place like this.

Downstairs, the pub is still just the pub. A bit noisy some nights, sure, but hardly extraordinary. It’s only when you get up these stairs that you realise something’s changing.

Word gets out. A glowing feature in the music magazine Select sends new faces across the threshold. The line on Bayham Street gets longer. Journalists start dropping in with notebooks and opinions. One music paper eventually calls Blow Up “the club that changed the world.” It’s hyperbole, of course – but in the mid-90s, it doesn’t feel completely mad.

Because what’s happening in this room isn’t just about who’s here; it’s about the way the past and present are being stitched together.

On any given night you might hear a Small Faces track from 1967, a punk single from 1978, and then a brand-new band from down the road in Camden – and they all sit together as if they’re part of the same conversation. The clothes, the haircuts, the way people move – it all starts to coalesce into a look and a sound the press will soon label Britpop.

From here, it spills outward. Into other Camden pubs and venues. Onto record sleeves and Top of the Pops. Suddenly, this little upstairs room is part of a much bigger picture.

Of course, in Camden, wild nights often end with a conversation about licences.

As the 1990s roll on, pressure builds over late opening hours and noise. Residents complain, council officers visit, letters go back and forth. It’s the classic tug-of-war between nightlife and sleep.

By the late ’90s, The Laurel Tree’s time as a music hotspot is winding down. Blow Up leaves for a larger Soho venue. The pub eventually closes, and for a while the building drifts through new identities: Bar 113, an Italian restaurant, a Japanese place.

Then, in 2011, it comes roaring back as BrewDog Camden – the Scottish craft-beer brand’s first English outpost. The décor changes, the taps are fancier, the playlists are different… but the bones of the building stay the same.

Even now, with BrewDog gone and the site between lives again, the old pub is still unmistakable.

Take another look around you.
Notice those tall upper windows and imagine the silhouettes behind them: dancers, drinkers, future Britpop stars shouting in each other’s ears over the music. Out here on the pavement, picture the queue, the fashion, the cigarettes, the excited argument about which new band is going to be huge.

To everyone else on the street today, this might be just another closed bar. To you, it’s a reminder that music history often happens in places that look… frankly, pretty normal.

Not in arenas. Not in glamorous palaces. In hot, cramped rooms over working pubs on back streets like Bayham Street.

As you head on to your next stop, you’re following the same routes those bands and fans once took – from anonymous queues outside little venues, out into the bright, noisy world of Camden, and on towards the big stages where Britpop would make its mark.

And it all helps you see this corner of London for what it really is: not just a place on the map, but one of the small rooms where a whole era learned how to dance.

title: Dingwalls
inscription:
On the edge of Regent’s Canal, just by Hampstead Road Lock, stands a fairly ordinary-looking brick warehouse with “T.E. Dingwall” fading high on the wall.

It doesn’t look like much.

And yet, in the dark room behind those doors, only a few hundred people at a time have watched Pulp, Blur, Oasis, Blondie, The Clash, Foo Fighters, Coldplay – and plenty more – before they were too big for anywhere this small. This is Dingwalls: 500 people, world-famous bands, and a lot of sticky floors in between.
address: East Yard, 11 Camden Lock Pl, London NW1 8AL
lead_subject_bio:
You’re standing on the edge of Regent’s Canal, just by Hampstead Road Lock, facing a fairly ordinary-looking brick warehouse with “T.E. Dingwall” fading high on the wall.

It doesn’t look like much.

And yet, in the dark room behind those doors, only a few hundred people at a time have watched Pulp, Blur, Oasis, Blondie, The Clash, Foo Fighters, Coldplay – and plenty more – before they were too big for anywhere this small. This is Dingwalls: 500 people, world-famous bands, and a lot of sticky floors in between.

From packing crates to power chords

Before there were mosh pits and merch stalls, this was simply a piece of working London.

For most of the 19th and 20th centuries, the canal in front of you was an industrial motorway. Barges brought timber and goods into Camden’s yards. T.E. Dingwall, whose name still clings to the brick, ran a timber packing-case business here after the Second World War. This was a place for boxes – plain wooden crates designed to carry someone else’s products, someone else’s story.

Then the 1970s arrived, and Camden decided it wanted stories of its own.

As the old goods yards turned into Camden Lock Market, a group of entrepreneurs looked at this rather tired warehouse by the water and thought: dancehall. They cleared the sawdust, put in a stage, and christened it Dingwalls Dance Hall. Overnight, this anonymous workplace became a late-night magnet with a bar famously boasted as “the longest in London” and a rare 2am licence in an era when most pubs shut at eleven.

You can imagine the draw: you could drink, dance, and watch a live band here until two in the morning while the rest of the city put the kettle on and went to bed.

Punk folklore and New York visitors

Very quickly, Dingwalls became one of the loudest addresses in London.

Pub rock bands and then early punk acts tore through this room: Kilburn and the High Roads, The Clash, Sex Pistols, The Stranglers, Desmond Dekker. According to Camden folklore, there was even a punch-up outside involving members of the Stranglers, the Clash and the Pistols – the kind of messy, half-remembered night that newspaper columnists and punk biographers dine out on.

Inside, the venue was gaining a reputation as a place where London met the rest of the world. One of the most famous nights came when a then-up-and-coming New York band called Blondie played one of their first UK gigs here. Imagine Debbie Harry stepping onto a small stage in this dark little hall, canal water slapping gently against the outside wall while inside, Camden got its first proper taste of New York new wave.

The pattern was already forming: whatever was new and noisy sooner or later passed through Dingwalls.

Sunday service: acid jazz in a crate shed

By the late 1980s, the punk and pub-rock wave had rolled on, and the venue shape-shifted yet again.

Now picture it on a Sunday afternoon. Daylight slipping in through high windows. No punk safety pins, but dancers in baggy trousers and baseball caps. The sound is tight drums, complex bass lines and shimmering jazz chords.

This was the home of the acid jazz sessions run by DJs like Gilles Peterson – legendary Sunday daytime parties with names like “Talkin’ Loud and Saying Something.” In a building that once stored timber, people were suddenly treating intricate jazz-funk as sacred as any religious service… just with more record collectors and fewer hymn books.

Same bricks. Different beat.

Look around you

Take a moment to really look around you.

There’s the lock in front of you, with narrowboats nudging through. There are tourists with coffee cups, market stalls selling street food, and above, a terrace bar where people photograph the sunset over the canal.

Now imagine stripping all of that away: no tourists, no Instagram, just a rougher Camden where this warehouse is one of the few places you can stay out late. That sense of being slightly off the map – that’s the energy Britpop would feed on.

Britpop in a shoebox

By the late 1980s and early 90s, the seeds of Britpop were being planted here.

In 1988, Pulp played a Christmas party for a music magazine inside this building – their first gig with a new bassist called Steve Mackey. At the time, they were still years away from Common People, but nights like that are where the long climb began: a curious crowd, some new songs, and a band still working out who they were.

Then there was Blur – not yet the polished, art-school Britpop icons, but a chaotic, slightly wild young band playing early London shows in rooms like this. One oft-repeated story from Dingwalls has security allegedly macing the band on stage when their antics got a bit too much. Whether or not every detail is true, it tells you something about the atmosphere: this was not the polite, Brit Awards version of the 90s. This was messy, loud and unpredictable.

As the decade rolled on, Oasis and other soon-to-be-huge bands took turns on this stage. Record-label scouts clustered near the mixing desk, trying to guess who’d be the next big signing. Within a couple of years, some of these acts would be playing stadiums and topping charts. For now, they were squeezed into a 500-capacity room by a canal lock.

Look around you again

Glance at the doors and windows, the slightly cramped entrance.

Now imagine a 90s crowd forcing their way in: parkas, Adidas trainers, carefully cultivated fringes; a sea of people convinced they’re part of something important. The lights go down, the band steps on, and for an hour the outside world shrinks to this rectangle of stage and sweat.

That’s the real magic of Dingwalls: not that famous bands have played here, but that for those in the room, they didn’t feel famous yet. They felt possible.

Secret shows, new names, same old bricks

Even after the Britpop wave receded, the pattern continued.

In the 2000s and beyond, global names used Dingwalls as a place to reconnect with audiences at arm’s length. Bands like The Strokes slipped onto this stage under fake names. Coldplay turned up for an intimate radio concert. Noel Gallagher came back to Camden for a tiny charity show. Tribute nights and Britpop club events filled the gaps, keeping the 90s nostalgia alive.

At one point, a legal tangle over the Dingwalls name meant the venue briefly re-branded as The PowerHaus, after an old North London club. Locals grumbled, but the important bit never changed: the room, the canal, the sense that something interesting might happen here again tonight. Eventually, the Dingwalls name returned to the sign – a satisfying moment for Camden’s collective memory.

Echoes on the water

So, what are you really looking at?

A Victorian crate shed. A 70s punk dive with “the longest bar in London.” An acid-jazz temple. A Britpop launchpad. A place where stadium bands come to feel nervous again.

All of those versions of Dingwalls are stacked on top of each other in the same few metres of brick and timber.

As you listen to the water sliding through the lock, you’re standing in a kind of echo chamber for British music history. Each new generation has brought its own soundtrack through those doors, complained that it’s not as good as the last lot, and then watched their memories turn into legend.

When you move on to the next stop, keep an ear out. Somewhere nearby, in another cramped room, a band you’ve never heard of is doing a soundcheck, dreaming of the day someone adds their name to the long, unlikely list of acts who once made a small Camden venue feel like the centre of the world.

title: Dublin Castle
inscription: The Dublin Castle is a narrow Victorian pub front: red paintwork, old brick above, a strip of windows with gig posters peeling a little at the corners. There might be a few smokers huddled by the doorway, pints in hand, talking too loudly for the size of the pavement, and yet, from Irish navvies to Madness, Britpop and Amy Winehouse, this tiny pub has launched more careers than some record labels.
lead_subject_bio:
You’re standing outside the Dublin Castle on Parkway – and at first glance, it doesn’t look like the sort of place that helped change British music.

It’s just a narrow Victorian pub front: red paintwork, old brick above, a strip of windows with gig posters peeling a little at the corners. There might be a few smokers huddled by the doorway, pints in hand, talking too loudly for the size of the pavement.

And yet, from Irish navvies to Madness, Britpop and Amy Winehouse, this tiny pub has launched more careers than some record labels.

Take a moment to look around you.

You’re slightly off the main tourist drag of Camden Town here – away from the market chaos and souvenir stalls. Parkway still feels like a real working street: cafés, small shops, a couple of other pubs. Dublin Castle sits modestly in the row, the sort of place you might walk past without a second glance.

But for decades, hopeful bands have stood exactly where you’re standing now, shuffling nervously with guitar cases and drum hardware, wondering if tonight is the night someone important happens to be at the bar.

Let’s rewind a bit.

In the mid-1800s, Camden wasn’t a cool postcode. It was practical. The Regent’s Canal and, later, the railways turned this area into a hub for warehouses, stables and yards. The people who kept all of that moving – dockers, carters, railway workers, labourers from all over Britain and Ireland – needed somewhere to drink.

That’s where pubs like this come in.

Dublin Castle appears in the records from the mid-19th century, with hints of an earlier pub on this spot going back to the 1820s. The name is a pretty big clue to its early clientele: there were a lot of Irish workers in the area, and this was one of the places where they could feel vaguely at home at the end of a long, miserable shift.

For years it was just that – a local. Pints, gossip, arguments, card games, and, later on, traditional Irish music sessions. No one was talking about “scenes” or “A&R scouts”. It was simply the sort of pub every industrial district needed.

There’s a colourful local legend you might hear on some tours: apparently, Dublin Castle was one of a chain of “castle pubs” – Dublin, Edinboro, Windsor – supposedly built to keep Irish, Scots and English workers drinking separately, to stop them fighting in the same bar. It’s a neat story… and probably nonsense. Historians haven’t found any solid evidence of a grand segregation plan. It’s more likely that the pubs just borrowed grand place names because they sounded respectable.

Still, the fact that people want that story to be true tells you something about Camden: it’s a place where myth and history happily share a pint.

Fast-forward to the late 1970s, and Camden is changing again.

Punk has ripped through London, Two-Tone and ska are on the rise, and there’s a new energy pulsing through the pubs and basements. Up the road, places like Dingwalls and the Roundhouse are booking bands that will soon be on TV. The question is: where do they come from before that?

In Dublin Castle, the key figure is the landlord, Alo Conlon.

Picture him: sitting at the end of the bar or near the door, listening with a practiced ear. No algorithm. No committee. Just one man deciding whether a band is worth a repeat booking.

Into this walks a group of local lads, calling themselves The Camden Invaders, and later, Madness.

The story goes that when they first asked for a gig here, they told Alo they were a jazz band – because jazz sounded respectable, and ska absolutely did not. He took a chance, gave them a slot, and when they hit their first off-beat, the whole room started to move. Word spread quickly: there was a new sound in this small back room, and it was irresistible.

Madness got a residency. The pub filled up with fans and curious locals, crammed shoulder-to-shoulder, pints balanced precariously as people tried to dance without spilling everything. The band even shot the video for “My Girl” here. Overnight, Dublin Castle wasn’t just a neighbourhood local anymore – it was somewhere you might discover something.

That one booking changed the pub’s trajectory. Alo realised that if he chose the right bands, he could turn this tiny room into a serious music stop.

By the late ’80s and early ’90s, that little back room had become a kind of unofficial exam for new bands.

Step inside if you can, or just imagine it from where you’re standing.

The gig space isn’t huge. A low stage at one end, the bar at the other, and not much distance in between. The ceiling feels slightly too low for the amount of noise it has to contain. There’s a sound desk wedged into a corner and a tangle of cables that definitely weren’t installed by an interior designer.

Now picture a four-piece indie band setting up: nervous, slightly sweaty, fiddling with guitar leads. At the bar, there might be a couple of record label people, a journalist, and a DJ who knows everyone. If you win over this room, with this crowd, people talk.

This is where the Dublin Castle becomes part of the Britpop story.

Before they were playing festivals, bands like Blur, Coldplay and Supergrass were squeezing onto stages exactly like this one – and sometimes onto this stage specifically. The Dublin Castle was one of the places they had to pass through on their way up the ladder, the musical equivalent of an old-fashioned driving test: no frills, no mercy.

If Alo liked you, you got another gig. If the regulars liked you, they brought their mates next time. And if the right person happened to be leaning on the bar that night, nursing a Guinness and taking mental notes… well, that’s how careers started.

Music journalists and radio people knew this. Steve Lamacq, one of the great champions of indie and alternative music, once called Dublin Castle his second home. Turning up here to see who was on the bill was part of the job.

So while it’s a bit of an exaggeration to call this the birthplace of Britpop – the whole thing has roots in Essex, Manchester, all over – it’s fair to say this room was one of its incubators.

Then the 2000s roll in, and Camden reinvents itself again, this time with a new queen: Amy Winehouse.

She’s now one of the most mythologised figures in Camden’s recent history, and the Dublin Castle is one of the places most closely linked to those stories. This wasn’t just a venue she played; it was one of her locals. People remember her drinking here, hopping up for impromptu performances and, occasionally, stepping behind the bar to pull pints.

There’s something very “Dublin Castle” about that. The line between musician and regular is blurry. One night you’re just another face at the bar; the next, you’re on stage. Or the other way round.

Imagine standing in that back room on a random Tuesday night in the early 2000s. Maybe you’d see a new band destined for obscurity. Maybe you’d see a set that people would talk about for years. Maybe Amy herself would be in the corner, scribbling lyrics on a napkin.

The point is: this place isn’t just a venue where famous people passed through. It’s somewhere they felt comfortable hanging around.

Let’s zoom back out to today.

Look around you again.

Notice how ordinary it all looks. A small pub sign. A few posters advertising tonight’s bands. If you spot a heritage plaque for Madness or a framed photo from a past gig, that’s the only real hint that any of this mattered to the wider world.

Behind that door, though, the basic deal hasn’t changed for decades: turn up, load in, plug in, and hope the room likes you.

Camden has seen wave after wave of gentrification and reinvention. Big venues have closed, reopened, rebranded. Pubs have become cocktail bars, vegan diners, or flats. And yet the Dublin Castle is still here, still family-run, still booking bands most nights of the week.

Alo Conlon has long since passed on, but his family have kept the place going. The faces have changed, the bands have changed, the hairstyles have definitely changed – but if you strip away the smartphones and the contactless payments, a Friday night here now is not so different from a Friday night in 1979.

That’s the real magic of this place.

It’s not a museum to Britpop, or a frozen shrine to Madness, or an Amy Winehouse theme bar. It’s a functioning, slightly scruffy, totally alive grassroots venue that just happens to have a ridiculous history.

So as you get ready to head to your next stop, take a final look at the frontage and imagine it at three different moments in time.

In the 1880s: tired labourers in flat caps pushing through the door, grateful for a drink after a brutal shift on the canal or the railway.

In 1979: teenage ska fans piling in to see Madness, the air thick with cigarette smoke and the sense that something is happening.

In the mid-’90s or early 2000s: scruffy guitar bands lugging amps past you, Amy Winehouse laughing with friends at the bar, and a couple of industry people pretending not to be on the lookout for their next signing.

Same doorway. Same tiny room. Entirely different futures being decided inside.

As you walk away towards the next venue on your tour, remember this: most “overnight” successes don’t start with a big stage and fireworks. They start in places like the Dublin Castle – on sticky floors, under low ceilings, with a handful of half-interested strangers who might, just might, be the first people to see something special.

title: The Falcon
inscription: For a chunk of the late 80s and 90s, this unassuming corner – The Falcon, or Camden Falcon – was one of the loudest, most influential shoeboxes in British guitar music. In a space that barely held 150 people, bands like Blur, Pulp, Suede, Lush, The Verve, Super Furry Animals and a very young Coldplay all sweated it out on a tiny back-room stage.
lead_subject_bio:
You’re standing on a quiet Camden back street, looking at what seems to be… absolutely nothing special. A corner block of flats. A few windows. A buzzer panel. Maybe a bike locked to a railing.

But for a chunk of the late 80s and 90s, this unassuming corner – The Falcon, or Camden Falcon – was one of the loudest, most influential shoeboxes in British guitar music. In a space that barely held 150 people, bands like Blur, Pulp, Suede, Lush, The Verve, Super Furry Animals and a very young Coldplay all sweated it out on a tiny back-room stage.

Take a moment to look up at the building in front of you.
Imagine a pub sign where the modern windows are. Picture a narrow bar on the ground floor, nicotine-stained ceiling, cheap lager on tap. Somewhere behind that façade, hidden now behind plasterboard and IKEA furniture, there used to be a back room – low ceiling, tiny stage, just enough space to wedge in a drum kit and a few amps. That was the Falcon’s gig room.

Camden’s big venues – Dingwalls, the Electric Ballroom, the Roundhouse – get the glory. But back then, the real magic often happened in places like this: slightly off the main drag, where the tourists didn’t stray, and where the industry did.

In the late 1980s, promoter Jeff Barrett started running a night here with a wonderfully obscure name: the Phil Kaufman Club. On a typical evening you’d have a tangle of guitar leads on the floor, handwritten flyers Blu-Tacked to the wall, and a crowd of people who looked like they either wrote fanzines… or should have. Label scouts leaned on the bar. Journalists pretended not to be label scouts. The regulars just wanted a pint and a bit of peace.

This is where The Sundays played their first ever gig – nervous, jangly, and instantly whispered about. House of Love blew the doors off more than once. Heavenly, Pale Saints, and a swarm of other indie hopefuls took turns on the tiny stage. After one of those sets, a label boss would lean over and say, “We should talk.” For bands on the make, a good night at The Falcon could change everything.

The sound here wasn’t polished; it wasn’t meant to be. The Falcon’s back room became a natural home for the rising tide of shoegaze and noise bands. Lush, Slowdive, The Telescopes, Silverfish, Th’ Faith Healers – walls of guitar, feedback hanging in the air, vocals nearly drowned in reverb. In a big venue, that kind of sound can feel distant. In a room this size, it’s like standing inside the amplifier.

Picture it: condensation on the ceiling, your ears ringing, the front row close enough to read the song titles on the setlist gaffer-taped to the floor. People spilling out into the corridor, craning their necks through the doorway just to catch a glimpse of the stage. It was chaotic, rough around the edges, and that was the point.

Some writers later called this the “Camden Lurch” scene – slightly shambolic, noisy, stubbornly unglamorous. Exactly the kind of thing that doesn’t make sense on paper, but feels electric at 11pm after three pints.

At the same time, the Falcon was quietly becoming a star factory. Label bosses from 4AD saw Lush and Pale Saints here and decided they belonged on the roster. Sarah Records fell for Heavenly in this room. A few years later, Creation’s Alan McGee would watch Super Furry Animals here and decide they were worth taking a punt on. And a young Coldplay played a show so convincing that the Fierce Panda label boss started plotting a single for them on the way home.

And then there’s the Oasis story – the sort of slightly unbelievable anecdote Camden thrives on. One October day in 1993, Oasis signed their big deal with Creation and Sony. Afterwards, they headed here, to the Falcon, where another band was meant to be headlining. Depending on who you ask, Oasis either snuck on for a quick, ramshackle celebration set… or commandeered the night entirely. What everyone agrees on is that it was messy, loud, and very Oasis.

By the mid-90s, The Falcon’s regular indie nights had coalesced into something more formal: The Barfly. The Barfly club brand – and later The Fly magazine – all trace their beginnings back to this corner. The operation eventually outgrew the pub and moved to a larger venue up the road, but this was the original laboratory. There are stories of magazine offices upstairs, late-night layout sessions, and at least one ill-advised candle that got a bit too ambitious and caused a serious scare. Those details live in people’s memories more than in official records, but you get the idea: it was organised chaos.

Now, take another look around you.
Check the doorbells. The intercom panel. The neat paintwork. Try to map what you see now onto what was here before. Which flat might have been the Barfly office? Where would bands have lugged gear in, sweating and swearing, trying not to rip their trousers on the door frame? Whose bedroom now occupies the corner where a drum kit once sat, making the windows vibrate?

Locals talk about the building suffering at least one serious fire before it finally stopped trading as a pub and was folded into the tide of residential conversions. However many times it burned, the result is what you’re seeing: an ex-venue smoothed over into anonymity. No plaque. No sign. Just another corner in Camden.

And that’s the bigger story this place tells. Cities like London are full of “ghost venues” – tiny rooms where culture changed course a fraction of a degree, enough to shape what the rest of us heard on the radio a few years later. They rarely get blue plaques or heritage tours. They get plastered, partitioned, wired for broadband and turned into someone’s lounge.

Next time you scroll past a playlist called “90s Indie” or “Britpop Classics”, remember that some of those tracks can be traced back to nights exactly like the ones that happened here – a cramped room, cheap beer, someone at the back thinking, “These lot might be going somewhere.”

And as you head on to the next stop, keep this place in the corner of your eye. Because if this quiet block of flats can claim early Blur, shoegaze feedback and an impromptu Oasis victory lap, who knows what histories are hiding behind the next perfectly ordinary door.

title: Camden Palace (now KOKO)
inscription:
You could be forgiven for thinking that you’re standing outside a slightly over-dressed nightclub – white façade, fancy dome, big KOKO sign – at one of the noisiest junctions in Camden. Buses roar past, someone’s vape cloud drifts by… and yet this corner has been a stage for more than a century of music, comedy and chaos.

This isn’t just a club. It’s a shape-shifter. One dome, a hundred and twenty-odd years of different scenes.
lead_subject_bio:
You’re standing outside what looks like a slightly over-dressed nightclub – white façade, fancy dome, big KOKO sign – at one of the noisiest junctions in Camden. Buses roar past, someone’s vape cloud drifts by… and yet this corner has been a stage for more than a century of music, comedy and chaos.

This isn’t just a club. It’s a shape-shifter. One dome, a hundred and twenty-odd years of different scenes.

Take a moment and look up.

Pick out the curves of that coppery dome, the columns, the arched windows. It feels a bit grand for a gig venue, doesn’t it? That’s because, when this place opened on Boxing Day 1900, it was trying to rival the West End.

Back then, this was the Camden Theatre – a brand new palace of entertainment in what was still slightly fringe territory. They even brought in star power for opening night: the great Victorian actor Ellen Terry, sweeping in to declare the place open. Inside, you’d have found velvet seats, chandeliers, and a smart Edwardian crowd in their best evening wear, here for operetta, Shakespeare and a bit of musical comedy.

Within a decade it was the Camden Hippodrome, chasing variety audiences, then it reinvented itself again as a cinema. So even before rock ’n’ roll was invented, this building had already decided it would do whatever it took to keep the seats full.

Then the BBC moved in.

Jump to the late 1940s and 50s, and the theatre is no longer selling tickets at all. It’s become the BBC’s Camden Theatre – a kind of factory for radio shows.

If you’d stood roughly where you are now on a recording night, you’d have seen a very British sort of queue: flat caps, headscarves, couples in their Sunday best, all patiently waiting for a free night out courtesy of the BBC.

Inside, under that same dome, they recorded The Goon Show, Hancock’s Half Hour, and later, material with the Monty Python team. Some of the most quoted lines in British comedy bounced off these plasterwork balconies before they ever reached a wireless in someone’s front room.

So the bones of the place – the balconies, the boxes, the sweep of the auditorium – stayed the same. The orchestra pit that once held musicians now had sound engineers and microphones. Same room, totally different kind of laughter.

By the mid-1970s, radio comedy was on the way out and the building faced demolition. Instead, it did what it always does: it reinvented itself.

In 1977 it reopened as The Music Machine, and the polite BBC audience gave way to punks and new wavers. Bands like The Clash, The Jam, the Boomtown Rats and a parade of others roared across the stage. The red velvet and Baroque flourishes were still there, but now they were bathed in harsh stage lights and cigarette smoke.

There’s a persistent story – you’ll hear it echoed by locals and rock historians – that this was the last place AC/DC’s singer Bon Scott drank before his death in 1980. It’s hard to prove, but it’s become part of the building’s mythology: the idea that rock ’n’ roll excess, as well as music, leaves a trace in the walls.

Then, in the early 1980s, the doors opened again under a new name: Camden Palace.

Have another look around you and try to overlay the 1980s on what you see.

Same entrance, but the queue is now pure New Romantic and early club culture: towering hair, eyeliner on everyone, frilly shirts, leather trousers, outfits that look like they’ve escaped from a particularly stylish pirate ship. Inside, Camden Palace became a hotspot for synthpop, fashion, and the more theatrical end of post-punk.

Tuesday nights there was “Feet First” – a rock and alternative club night where the dancefloor would turn into a mosh pit and the balconies shook under the weight of people in creaking leather and Doc Martens.

It was here, in this slightly over-the-top former theatre, that Londoners first got a glimpse of a young Madonna onstage – at least, that’s how the story is usually told. Decades later, after she’d become Madonna with a capital M, she’d come back to the same building, by then renamed KOKO, for a tiny, high-energy promo show. Not many venues get to host both an unknown and a global icon in the same room.

By the early 1990s, Camden Palace was also dipping its toes into acid house, rave and early dance nights, all layered on top of its rock and New Romantic past. And that’s where your Britpop story starts to intersect.

In the early 90s, Camden became the unofficial capital of a new guitar scene that didn’t yet have a label. Bands lived round here, drank round here, rehearsed in grimy basements and played tiny rooms in the pubs you’ll visit elsewhere on this tour.

Camden Palace was one rung up the ladder – bigger than a back-room pub, but still intimate enough to feel dangerous.

In 1990, Blur played here, still in their early, slightly uncertain phase, trying to work out exactly what kind of band they were going to be.

In 1992, Suede arrived, all sharp cheekbones and feedback. Fans remember the balcony shaking as the crowd hurled itself around to “Animal Nitrate”-era songs. The place felt overheated and overloaded, like something was about to happen and no one had quite put a name to it yet.

That same year Pulp played here too – still a cult Sheffield band rather than a household name, but building the momentum that would make Jarvis Cocker a national figure a few years later.

If you picture the balconies above you now, imagine them rammed with early-90s kids in charity-shop blazers, band T-shirts and big boots, leaning over the rail. Below, the floor heaving, sweat rising towards the dome as these songs – not yet “classics”, just new, noisy tunes – crashed into the old theatre decor.

Before the magazine covers and Britpop compilations, conquering a room like this was one of the signs you were getting somewhere.

In 2004, the venue got yet another new life. After a major restoration, the building reopened as KOKO. The capacity was trimmed down, the sound and lighting were modernised, and new bars and spaces were threaded through the old structure.

Suddenly, it was a place where huge acts came to do small shows. Coldplay launched an album here. Prince slipped in for surprise gigs. Arcade Fire, Kanye West, countless others have used this room when they wanted to feel a real crowd up close rather than a stadium blur.

Then, in 2020, disaster struck again. A serious fire ripped through the roof during renovation. For a while, it looked like the dome you’re looking at now might not survive at all.

But it did. After an eye-watering rebuild, KOKO reopened in 2022 as a sprawling complex: music venue, studios, members’ club, rooftop spaces – all wrapped around that original 1900 auditorium.

So what you see in front of you is both survivor and newcomer: a building that has literally been through the flames and come back, once again, as something slightly different.

Before you head on, take one last look along Camden High Street. Think about the people who’ve streamed through these doors: Edwardian theatre-goers in opera cloaks; BBC audiences laughing at The Goons; punks and New Romantics in impossible outfits; early Britpop fans, ears ringing; tonight’s crowd checking their phones for stage times.

For your Britpop story, this place is the “big room” – the upgrade step from the cramped pub stages. Your next stops will take you back into those smaller spaces, the sticky-floored bars and back rooms where bands like Blur, Suede and Pulp first made a noise and hoped, one day, to see their name on the bill right here.

The dome above you has heard all of it. And it’s still listening.

title: Food Records office
inscription:
Behind these fairly anonymous windows, in the 1990s, people were deciding which songs would end up stuck in your head for months at a time.

This is 172A Arlington Road – once the home of Food Records, the label that signed Blur and helped turn Britpop from a scruffy idea into a full-blown moment in British culture.
lead_subject_bio:
You’re standing on what looks like a pretty ordinary Camden side street. A few cars, a bit of traffic noise drifting up from Parkway, a mix of flats and offices.

But behind these fairly anonymous windows, in the 1990s, people were deciding which songs would end up stuck in your head for months at a time.

This is 172A Arlington Road – once the home of Food Records, the label that signed Blur and helped turn Britpop from a scruffy idea into a full-blown moment in British culture.

Look up at the building in front of you.
Today it’s just another chunk of “creative office space”: open-plan desks, laptops, probably some plants and a half-broken coffee machine.

Now imagine it thirty years ago. The walls are plastered with posters: Blur, Jesus Jones, Dubstar. Phones are ringing. There are piles of demo cassettes, envelopes stuffed with fan mail, and someone is desperately trying to work out which track should be the A-side.

Food Records began life back in 1984, set up by David Balfe – a veteran of the post-punk scene and former member of The Teardrop Explodes. Before long he was joined by Andy Ross, a sharp-eared, sharp-tongued A&R man who loved arguing about music almost as much as signing it.

At first, Food was a scrappy little indie operation, licensing records through bigger companies, hustling to get oddball guitar bands onto daytime radio. It wasn’t some faceless corporation; it was small, slightly chaotic, and very personal. The kind of place where a new single could be green-lit after a fierce discussion over takeaway curry and a stack of NME reviews.

And it wasn’t just Blur. Food’s roster included acts like Jesus Jones, Idlewild, Dubstar, Shampoo and The Supernaturals – proof that the label had a knack for finding bands just off the centre of things and nudging them into the mainstream.

Now, let’s bring Blur into the frame.

Rewind to the late 1980s. London’s small venues are full of hopeful bands with terrible names. One of them is called Seymour. They’re playing places like the Powerhaus in Islington: sticky floors, warm beer, and a sound that’s still taking shape.

Andy Ross goes to see them, and he hears something he likes. He and Balfe offer the band a deal on Food – with one condition: the name has to go.

Over dinner at a Soho pizzeria, they kick names around until they land on something short, punchy and, crucially, easy to put on a T-shirt: Blur.

From that point on, more and more of the action in Blur’s story runs through this address. 172A Arlington Road starts appearing on CD sleeves and fan-club forms as the Food Records contact point – the place you’d write to if you wanted a T-shirt, a poster, or just to tell the band how much that one song meant to you.

The early releases – “She’s So High”, the album Leisure – are promising rather than era-defining. But then comes a shift: the band lean hard into a distinctly British sound and look. Out go some of the baggy, shoegazey ideas; in comes the sharp, observational world of Modern Life Is Rubbish and, soon after, Parklife.

And as those records roll out, a lot of decisions about artwork, single choices, tour promotion and press strategy are being made… here. On this street. In an upstairs office that, from the outside, looks no different from the one your dentist might use.

Take another moment to look around you.
If you glance down towards Parkway, you’re only a short stroll from Camden Town Underground station, the markets, the Jazz Café, the Underworld – all the venues and hangouts that gave Britpop its Camden “home turf”.

In the mid-nineties, you could get off the Tube, grab a copy of NME from the newsstand, and somewhere very close to this doorway, someone from Food Records would also be checking the reviews, seeing if this week’s single had been adored, mocked, or – worst of all – ignored.

Inside, imagine a typical day in Food HQ.

It’s mid-morning. The fax machine is spluttering out tour dates and radio playlists. Someone’s on the phone to a promoter in Glasgow, trying to squeeze another gig into an already ridiculous schedule.

Andy Ross is arguing – in the most affectionate way – about track sequencing: should the single open the album, or is that too obvious? There are demo tapes on every flat surface. The kettle has just boiled for the third time without anyone actually making tea.

In another room, a junior staffer is working through the mail. There are letters from Germany asking about T-shirts, a carefully handwritten note from a teenager in Kent who feels like Blur are the only people who “get it”, and a soggy Jiffy bag containing a cassette from a band who swear they’re “the next big thing”. Some of this post will be answered. Some of it – honestly – won’t. But it all passes through this address.

Food wasn’t just a logo on the back of a CD. It was a small, very human group of people trying to balance passion, instinct and the awkward realities of chart positions and marketing budgets.

Now zoom out from the doorway and picture Camden as a whole.

This part of London became a genuine cluster in the Britpop era. Record labels, PR companies, magazines, venues – all crammed into a tight radius. In this very building, Food shared space with the PR firm Savage & Best, who handled campaigns for bands like Blur, Pulp and Elastica. Down the road, there were other labels and studios; up the hill in Primrose Hill sat Creation Records, home of Oasis.

It meant that you could, quite literally, bump into the Britpop industry on your lunch break. A journalist on their way to file reviews; a band on their way to a photo shoot; a PR racing between meetings; an A&R scout ducking into the pub to see half a set from the Next Big Thing.

From the outside, streets like Arlington Road looked like any other bit of north London. On the inside, they were quietly shaping what you heard on the radio, saw on Top of the Pops, and copied onto mixtapes for your mates.

By the late 1990s, things start to change. Blur become more experimental. The album 13 pushes them into darker, more personal territory, and it’s generally seen as the last of the big Food-era Blur records. Around the same time, the corporate machinery keeps grinding on; Food is gradually folded into Parlophone, and the label name itself quietly disappears.

The office changes hands. New tenants move in. The posters come down. The fan mail stops. The building becomes just another “media-friendly” office in a gentrifying Camden.

But the address remains: printed on old CD booklets, listed in fanzines, preserved in the memories of the people who worked here. For Britpop fans, 172A Arlington Road isn’t just a line in an address book – it’s a tiny but important co-ordinate in the map of the 1990s.

As you take a final look at the building, imagine the invisible soundtrack: the blur (no pun intended) of guitars, arguments, laughter, panic, and the occasional clink of bottles after a chart triumph.

From down here, it’s just brick, glass and a buzzer. But in its heyday, this was one of the places where the sound of modern British guitar music was assembled, polished, argued over, and finally sent out into the world.

When you’re ready, you can head back towards Parkway and Camden Town. As you walk, remember that behind a lot of plain, anonymous doors like this one, people were quietly deciding what your 1990s were going to sound like.

title: Creation Records HQ
inscription:
This is Regent’s Park Road, right in the heart of Primrose Hill’s very respectable “village”. Dog walkers, prams, expensive haircuts… and in front of you, 109: a modest, pale building with arched windows that looks like it should house a yoga studio, a design agency, or maybe a discreet accountant.

What it actually housed, in the 1990s, was one of the loudest addresses in British music. From behind this quiet doorway, a scrappy indie label called Creation Records helped blow Britpop into the mainstream – and turned a bunch of Manchester chancers called Oasis into the biggest band in the country.
lead_subject_bio:
You’re standing on Regent’s Park Road, right in the heart of Primrose Hill’s very respectable “village”. Dog walkers, prams, expensive haircuts… and in front of you, 109: a modest, pale building with arched windows that looks like it should house a yoga studio, a design agency, or maybe a discreet accountant.

What it actually housed, in the 1990s, was one of the loudest addresses in British music. From behind this quiet doorway, a scrappy indie label called Creation Records helped blow Britpop into the mainstream – and turned a bunch of Manchester chancers called Oasis into the biggest band in the country.

Take a moment to look around you.

You’ve got pastel terraces and polished railings, well-behaved cars nudging along the road, maybe the clink of coffee cups from a nearby café. Try to imagine a very different soundtrack: phones ringing, fax machines whining, demos blaring at full volume from upstairs, and a stream of hungover staff, musicians, and hopefuls squeezing through this door with armfuls of tapes and half-finished artwork.

This building didn’t always belong to the music business. Wind back to the Victorian era and it was the chapel of a boys’ home: hymns, charity sermons, improving lectures. Respectable, slightly worthy, absolutely not rock ’n’ roll.

Fast-forward to the 1970s and things loosen up. The chapel becomes a squat, then a scruffy little club and restaurant called The Howff. Sticky floors, cheap food, late nights, loud bands. It’s as if the building starts to tune itself to youth culture – first in the form of rough-edged gigs, and later as the nerve centre of a very different kind of noise: indie rock and record-company panic.

Creation Records begins nowhere near this kind of posh postcode. In 1983, a young Scot called Alan McGee – railway worker’s son, band manager, and professional enthusiast for loud guitars – decides that if the labels he likes won’t sign the bands he loves, he’ll just start his own.

He borrows a small amount of money from the bank, presses a single, runs club nights in a tiny London venue called The Living Room, and uses that as office, A&R department and social life, all in one. The label is named after a 60s band, The Creation, and the early releases are pure belief over business plan.

The bands are noisy, wilful, often brilliant: The Jesus and Mary Chain, Primal Scream, Felt, Ride, My Bloody Valentine, Teenage Fanclub. Creation’s identity is very clear from the start: if it’s a bit odd, a bit loud, a bit too much for the mainstream, it probably belongs here.

By the early 1990s, though, this little crusade has consequences. Putting out ambitious records is expensive. One album in particular – My Bloody Valentine’s “Loveless” – becomes legendary not just for the music, but for the time and money it eats. Creation comes dangerously close to collapsing under the weight of its own ambition.

To keep going, McGee sells half the label to Sony. Suddenly, the kids who built their world on photocopied sleeves and night buses are part-owned by a global corporation. It’s a deal that keeps the lights on and, indirectly, leads to the next act of the story… but it creates a permanent tension. Can you still be the righteous outsider when your landlord is a multinational?

This is the climate in which Creation settles into its HQ here, at 109 Regent’s Park Road. The address gives the label a fixed point: an official letterhead, a registered office, a place where bands, journalists and distributors can actually find them. Inside, it’s still closer to organised chaos than slick corporate. But on paper, it’s a real company now – with a Primrose Hill postcode to prove it.

The turning point arrives not in Primrose Hill, but hundreds of miles north, in Glasgow. In May 1993, McGee walks into a small venue called King Tut’s Wah Wah Hut and finds an unsigned band from Manchester insisting they should have been on the bill. They get a short slot. He watches. Within a song or two, he knows they’re special.

That band is Oasis.

Different versions of the story disagree on the exact details – how many songs they played, how long it took him to decide – but everyone agrees on the essentials: McGee moved very fast. Within weeks, Oasis are signed to Creation, and very soon their demos, contracts, artwork and endless logistics are being funnelled through this unassuming door on Regent’s Park Road.

From the outside, nothing has changed. Inside, the stakes have gone through the roof.

“Definitely Maybe” arrives in 1994 and smashes straight to Number One. The following year, “(What’s the Story) Morning Glory?” becomes one of the defining British albums of the decade. Singles like “Wonderwall” and “Don’t Look Back in Anger” turn into instant singalongs in pubs, clubs and football grounds across the country.

For Creation, this modest office becomes the control room of a cultural explosion. Staff who remember the early days talk about phones ringing off the hook, overseas licensing deals being hammered out at all hours, journalists camped on the line, and desperate hopefuls turning up with demo tapes because “this is where Oasis got signed”.

Have a look along the street again.

Face the direction of the railway bridge, towards Camden. Down there are the pubs and venues that made up the rest of the Britpop circuit: the Good Mixer, Camden’s clubs and markets, the Pembroke Castle a short walk away – Oasis’s local at one point – and just up the hill behind you, the infamous “Supernova Heights”, Noel Gallagher’s house at the height of his fame.

You’re standing not just outside an office, but in the middle of a small triangle of music history: the headquarters here, the drinking spots down there, the rock-star lifestyle just up the hill.

Of course, all of this comes at a price. McGee becomes a celebrity in his own right – showered with awards, courted by politicians, held up as the man who spotted the biggest British band of the decade. At the same time, his lifestyle goes into overdrive. Heavy drug use, constant pressure and endless demands begin to take a toll.

By the late 1990s, the magic and the madness that fuelled Creation start to burn out. The label continues to release records – not just Oasis, but Super Furry Animals, The Boo Radleys and others – yet the sense of a moment passes. Around 1999–2000, Creation winds down as a frontline label. The registered office moves on from this address. McGee eventually walks away.

And that leaves us… here.

Look back up at the arches and the paintwork of 109 Regent’s Park Road. There’s no plaque, no statue, no hint for a casual passer-by that some of the most familiar British records of the 1990s were shepherded from inside this very ordinary shell.

This is one of the themes of this tour: that the loudest moments of pop culture often happen in the most anonymous places. Someone’s front room, a backstreet studio, a borrowed club basement… or a former chapel on a posh north London street, reborn as Creation Records HQ.

When you’re ready, follow the line of the road down towards the railway bridge and Camden. As you go, imagine “Wonderwall” leaking out of every shop and pub you pass – and remember that a surprising amount of that noise started right here, behind a simple door with a very complicated history

title: Pembroke Castle
inscription:
Picture this: two drinkers walking into the same pub, a hundred years apart.
One’s a railway navvy, hands black with soot, pockets jangling with a week’s wages. The other’s a 1990s guitarist with Liam Gallagher hair and yesterday’s NME stuffed in his coat.
This is where both of them would have pushed in, shoulder to shoulder with London’s latest obsession. Same doorway, different soundtrack.
lead_subject_bio:
Picture this: two drinkers walking into the same pub, a hundred years apart.
One’s a railway navvy, hands black with soot, pockets jangling with a week’s wages.
The other’s a 1990s guitarist with Liam Gallagher hair and yesterday’s NME stuffed in his coat.

Now tilt your gaze to the building in front of you – the blue frontage, the corner doorway, the big arched windows. This is where both of them would have pushed in, shoulder to shoulder with London’s latest obsession. Same doorway, different soundtrack.

If you’d been here in the late 1800s, this wouldn’t be “Britpop territory”. It would feel like the edge of town – the railway lines running nearby, the canal close by, fresh brick terraces marching up the hill. The pub was already here, known as the Pembroke Castle, named after Pembroke Terrace, a solid Victorian corner house keeping the local workers watered.

Have a quick look up at the upper floors – the pale stucco, the tall sash windows, that slightly grand, classical trim perched above the painted pub front. It wasn’t designed as a rock ’n’ roll shrine. It was a place to get change for a shilling, compare bruises, and complain about the foreman.

And it wasn’t alone. Camden grew a little family of “castle” pubs – the Dublin Castle, the Edinboro Castle, the Windsor Castle and this one, the Pembroke Castle. Pub lore says they were each assigned to a different nationality of canal and railway workers: Irish at the Dublin, Scots at the Edinboro, English at the Windsor and the Welsh here at the Pembroke, supposedly to stop the fighting.

It’s a brilliant story… and almost certainly nonsense.

Historians have ruined the fun slightly by pointing out that the pubs opened decades apart, with no neat master plan to separate the nations. Still, like any good B-side, the legend survives because people want it to. And in Camden, the stories are often at least as loud as the facts.

Now roll the tape forward. By the late 1980s and early 90s, the big industrial drama has moved somewhere else. The railways are just part of the background hum. The neighbourhood’s getting smarter. And a little record label up the road decides to plant its flag here.

If you turn to look down the street towards Regent’s Park Road, you’re basically tracing the walk from Creation Records’ office to this bar. The distance is about one heated argument over B-sides, or two if someone mentions Blur.

Creation Records set up just around that corner – an indie label that would end up with a roster including The Jesus and Mary Chain, My Bloody Valentine, Primal Scream… and a scruffy band from Manchester called Oasis. Suddenly, this quiet pocket between Camden and Primrose Hill is full of musicians, journalists and A&R people, all in desperate need of a drink after listening to demos all day.

And when you’ve been cooped up in an office arguing about guitar tones, you don’t walk far. The Pembroke Castle is one of the nearest proper pubs. It isn’t cool in the way that Camden Market is cool. It’s just… handy. Which is exactly how great local pubs become unlikely pieces of pop history.

Fan guides talk about this place as the Gallagher brothers’ local – the spot where label staff and band members would drift after work, or before a night that would eventually end somewhere very expensive and very noisy. Picture the bar on a good night: some locals who’ve been here for years, a few media types trying to be invisible, and then a wave of Mancunian swagger crashing through the door, demanding pints and probably control of the jukebox.

One story Oasis fans like to tell is that Liam Gallagher was once arrested here, apparently while sporting a particularly ridiculous hat. That one lives firmly in the “rumour and legend” category – more likely to be repeated over a pint than quoted in a court record – but it gives you a sense of how this corner has long attracted both trouble and attention.

Now widen the frame a bit. In the 1990s, just up the hill, Primrose Hill itself becomes a tabloid character – the base camp of the “Primrose Hill set”. Actors, models, musicians, a blur of after-parties and paparazzi flashes. A little further again, in Belsize Park, Noel Gallagher’s infamous house, nicknamed “Supernova Heights”, is hosting parties so regular the neighbours probably knew the setlist.

From this spot, you’re standing on the route between all of that: Camden Town’s chaos behind you, the Creation office and Primrose Hill viewpoint off down the road, and Noel’s party palace further up the hill. You could have stepped off a train at Chalk Farm, walked a few minutes to this pub, grabbed a pint, wandered to the office to sign a contract, climbed the hill to watch the sun go down… and then headed up to Belsize Park for whatever passed for “after-hours” in Britpop.

Take another look around you now. To one side you’ve got the road sliding back towards the canal and the railway, that old industrial spine still running into the city. To the other, the Primrose Hill streets climbing away in pastel terraces and money. The Pembroke is wedged neatly between working London and aspirational London, which is exactly where you’d expect both navvies and rock stars to drink.

Step back mentally into the 19th century again for a moment. Those upper windows you can see would have glowed with gaslight and cigarette smoke, wage packets being turned into beer while men compared the day’s near-misses on the tracks. Fast forward a century: swap the gaslight for electric glare, the wage packets for record advances, the work songs for “Wonderwall” being murdered in the corner by someone with an acoustic guitar who really should know better.

Today, the pub wears all of this quite lightly. Inside, it’s a neighbourhood local: food, big screens on match day, a beer garden tucked away round the back, and the odd function room that’s hosted everything from comedy nights to birthday parties. On one level, it’s just another London pub trying to keep up with rising rents and changing tastes.

On another level, it’s a place that’s quietly soaked in stories – some documented, some disputed, some probably invented on the spot somewhere between the third and fourth pint.

As you glance back at that blue frontage, you can imagine the two regulars we started with, overlapping for a second. The Victorian labourer, boots still dusty from the line. The 1990s musician, trainers muddy from Primrose Hill and ears still ringing from the studio. Both of them pulling open the same door, stepping into the same fug of warmth and noise, both convinced that their era is the most important one this corner will ever see.

That’s the thing about this stretch of Camden and Primrose Hill: it keeps re-casting the same spaces for new dramas. First the railways, then the rock stars. Who knows what comes next.

For now, you’re standing at a crossing point between those two worlds. When you’re ready, you can follow the Britpop map downhill – towards the Good Mixer and the rest of Camden’s venues – or head round the corner towards Creation’s old office and up to the Primrose Hill viewpoint. Either way, this little “castle” has earned its place in your playlist of London stories.

title: Supernova Heights
inscription: The famous “Supernova Heights” sign above the door is gone in current estate photos; to a passer-by it reads as a very nice but not obviously rock-and-roll family house. However, this Georgian townhouse at 9 Steele’s Rd Belsize Park, became globally famous in the late 1990's as Noel Gallagher’s London home and an epicentre of Britpop-era partying.
lead_subject_bio:
You’re on a quiet, rather respectable north London street.
Nothing much seems to be happening. A row of tall, well-behaved townhouses, a few parked cars, trees, maybe a dog-walker or two.

Now imagine this same spot in the late 1990s – lenses clicking, cab doors slamming, music leaking out into the night. Because for a few wild years, the house in front of you wasn’t just an address. It was Supernova Heights – the most famous party house in Britpop London.

Look up at the façade: the tall windows, the steps, the neat front door. Today, it’s just another expensive north London home. Back then, fans and paparazzi knew it instantly. There was even a sign above the door announcing the name, like the title of an album: Supernova Heights – a nod, of course, to Oasis’s “Champagne Supernova”.

To understand why this house mattered, you have to wind back to the mid-90s. Oasis have exploded. (What’s the Story) Morning Glory? has turned Noel Gallagher from unemployed Mancunian guitarist into one of the most famous songwriters on the planet. Knebworth, number ones, wall-to-wall headlines.

On paper, this house is Noel’s grown-up move: a big London base in leafy Belsize Park, shared with his then-wife Meg Matthews. In reality, it becomes something else: a kind of ground zero for late-90s excess.

Inside, the rooms were reworked into a rock star’s playground. Think: high ceilings, big sofas, arcade machines, music gear, people drifting from room to room at four in the morning. Noel later joked that the place felt like a “cocaine arcade” – his phrase, not ours – a blur of noise, substances and strange conversations at strange hours. Even the cats, he says, were traumatised by the chaos.

And yet, strangely, the neighbours barely heard a thing. Noel had the place soundproofed so heavily that actor Bob Hoskins, who lived nearby, apparently called him “the quietest neighbour in Europe”. From the outside, it’s a polite north London terrace. On the inside, it’s Britpop Narnia.

Look around you for a moment. Notice how close the houses are, how sound carries on a normal evening. Picture that same street with black cabs arriving, famous faces slipping through this doorway, and a cluster of fans and photographers camping by the railings, just in case.

Reports from the time talk about supermodels in the kitchen, musicians in every room and a party that never quite ended. The truth is probably less glamorous and more messy than the legend, but the legend is powerful: for a while, this was the address where “everyone” went after the gig, after the awards show, after the club.

Of course, living inside a legend has a cost. The marriage between Noel and Meg comes under strain. Oasis itself is lurching between triumph and implosion. The constant attention at this door – the cameras, the gossip, the relentless demand for stories – becomes part of the pressure cooker.

Eventually, Noel sells up and moves on. The era of Supernova Heights, as his house, is over – and he’s spoken since with a mixture of nostalgia and relief about leaving it behind. The hangover after the supernova.

But the story of the building doesn’t stop there.
After Noel, the house stays firmly in the celebrity orbit. It’s bought by actor and socialite Davinia Taylor, a friend of the same Primrose Hill set who used to party here. Later, comedian David Walliams takes it on and gives the interior a serious makeover: fewer rock-and-roll relics, more high-end design and luxury bathrooms. At one point, it’s described in estate adverts as a three-bedroom house; later, after more building work, it’s reconfigured into more bedrooms again, with a slick modern interior, roof terrace and long garden.

When it comes back on the market, the asking price has leapt by a couple of million. And in every article, every glossy listing, one phrase keeps cropping up, like a magic spell to add a few extra zeros:

“Former home of Noel Gallagher. Once known as Supernova Heights.”

Have a look up and down Steele’s Road again. It’s a nice street, but it’s not Buckingham Palace. What’s changed isn’t the bricks, but the story. For estate agents, this is no longer just a Victorian townhouse. It’s a piece of pop-culture real estate. You’re not just buying square footage – you’re buying bragging rights, a link, however distant, to the moment when Oasis were the biggest band in Britain and this doorway was their unofficial after-party HQ.

It’s also a neat little example of how London absorbs its wildest stories. The sign over the door is gone. The parties are long over. Children might live here now; someone’s probably worrying about school runs and boiler pressure instead of guest lists and hangers-on.
