But if you know where to look, the ghost of Supernova Heights is still in the brickwork. Fans still wander past and take photos. Interviewers still ask Noel about “that house”. And every so often, when the property changes hands, the old name reappears in the headlines for a moment, like a chorus you can’t quite get out of your head.

As you stand here, you’re in the middle of a strangely ordinary shrine: a place where a specific slice of the 1990s – Britpop bravado, tabloid culture, celebrity north London – all collided. From the pavement it’s just another smart address. In the collective memory, it’s forever Supernova Heights.

When you move on from here, you might want to carry that thought with you: how many other quiet London streets are hiding stories just as loud as this one?

title: Noel’s first Camden flat
inscription: Noel Gallagher’s first home in Camden. Before Supernova Heights, before the celebrity parties and tabloid nicknames, this was the London foothold: a rented flat he shared with Meg Matthews, while Oasis were right on the brink of becoming huge.
lead_subject_bio:
Imagine yourself in the 1990s walking down this well-to-do Camden street…
Neat terraces, trees, blue plaques, the faint roar of Camden High Street in the distance.

Now imagine that just below your feet, in a cramped basement flat, a bloke from Manchester is quietly writing songs that will go on to soundtrack the decade.

That basement was Noel Gallagher’s first home in Camden. Before Supernova Heights, before the celebrity parties and tabloid nicknames, this was the London foothold: a rented flat he shared with Meg Matthews, while Oasis were right on the brink of becoming huge.

Take a moment to look around you.
Notice how grown-up this street feels: rows of 19th-century houses, iron railings, maybe a blue plaque or two further along. If you glance down, you’ll see the steps dropping away to basement level, and those half-buried windows where the light is always a bit dim.

Down there, in the early 90s, daily life was not glamorous. Think mismatched furniture, ashtrays overflowing, guitar cases leaning in corners, half-finished mugs of tea on every flat surface. Noel’s still splitting his time between London and the North, writing on the road, in hotel rooms, and here in this basement. Nobody’s calling him a “national treasure” yet; he’s just another musician trying to turn riffs and scraps of lyrics into something that might pay the rent.

It’s widely said – in local histories and fan guides – that while he lived in this flat, he worked up songs like “Wonderwall” and “Champagne Supernova”. Whether every line was written right here or finished off elsewhere, this is certainly where some of the ideas that made it onto (What’s the Story) Morning Glory? were hammered into shape. Not in a glossy studio, but in a slightly damp front room under the pavement.

So when you look down to those basement windows now, imagine Noel on the sofa with an acoustic guitar, looping the same four chords, changing one word, then another, muttering lines under his breath. What will become wedding dance songs and football terrace anthems starts life here as scribbled notes on the back of bills.

And then there’s the phone call.

Picture the scene: it’s a Tuesday morning after a heavy night. Noel’s in bed, nursing what he later calls a vicious hangover. The phone starts ringing. And keeps ringing. Whoever it is, they’re persistent.

Eventually, he shuffles out to the hall, picks up the receiver and lets rip – he’s not exactly in the mood for a chat. On the other end is his manager.

Once the swearing dies down, the manager gets to the point:

“Congratulations. You’ve officially just become a millionaire.”

No champagne, no confetti cannons. Just a groggy guitarist in a rented basement, suddenly having to get his head around the fact that those songs he’s been bashing out down here have turned into serious money.

Later on, Noel will say that, of all the big moments in his career – the sold-out gigs, the awards, the famous rows – that phone call is the one that stands out as his best memory. It happens right here, somewhere beneath where you’re standing.

If you look around you again, at the pavement, the steps and the railings, it’s strangely easy to imagine. One moment, this is just another slightly scruffy flat in Camden. The next, its tenant is a millionaire and the world outside those windows has shifted a few inches to the left.

Albert Street, though, didn’t suddenly become important because of Noel Gallagher. It already had a history.

Further along you’ll find proper blue plaques: Victorian writers, scientists, artists who lived and worked on this same street. Camden seems to collect creative energy. For more than a century, people have been holed up behind these facades, trying to wrestle ideas into shape – novels, theories, paintings… and, in the 1990s, rock songs.

So as you look up and down the terrace, you’re seeing layers of that history stacked on top of each other. Gas-lit Camden, post-war bohemia, the Britpop years – all sharing the same brickwork. Noel is just one more name in a surprisingly long guest list.

This flat also marks a turning point in his own story.

Here, he’s still close to normal life. The success is new; the money is only just starting to arrive. He and Meg are down at basement level like anyone else renting in Camden – sharing walls and arguments with the neighbours, lugging shopping up the steps, dodging the damp.

But soon after that phone call, things accelerate. Oasis blow up, and the basement gives way to something much bigger: the Belsize Park townhouse that Noel christens Supernova Heights, with soundproofed walls, celebrity guests and its own tabloid legend. That house, just up the road, becomes the “rock star palace”.

This place? This is the before picture.

Standing here, it’s easy to forget that. Today the flat below is almost certainly newly decorated, with clean paintwork and a distinctly non-rock-and-roll rent attached. Someone else lives there now; you’d hope they’re getting more sleep than Noel did.

From street level, there’s nothing to mark it out. No plaque, no sign, no indication that at one point a Tuesday morning phone call here announced a new millionaire, or that songs born under this pavement would end up playing over pub jukeboxes and supermarket radios for the next thirty-odd years.

As you get ready to move on, take one last look around you.

This is not a stadium, or a studio, or a grand ancestral home. It’s a basement flat on a London side street. And yet, for a little while in the 1990s, it was the centre of someone’s universe – the place where doubts turned into choruses, where bank balances flipped overnight, where a band’s future took a sharp upward turn.

Next time you hear “Wonderwall” drifting out of a bar, or you see footage of Oasis at Knebworth in front of a sea of people, you can picture a different image alongside it: a man in a small room, under a Camden pavement, noodling on a guitar and wondering if this next song might just be the one.

From here to Supernova Heights to stadium stages, it all runs along the same invisible route. And it passes right under your feet on this very street.

title: Abbey Road Studios
inscription:
On the face of it, you’re on a quiet, posh London street where the loudest thing is a taxi honking at tourists on the crossing. 
Yet some of the noisiest, most opinion-splitting albums of the 1990s were born just behind that modest white façade.

For Oasis, Radiohead and the rest, Abbey Road wasn’t a museum. It was a proving ground.
address: 3 Abbey Road, St John’s Wood NW8 9AY
lead_subject_bio:
Right now, you’re on one of the quietest “loud” streets in the world.

Taxi engines rumble, a bus sighs at the lights, a horn blares as someone in a parka stops dead in the road to take a photo. On the surface, it’s just a well-heeled bit of north-west London. But behind that modest white façade in front of you, and across this bit of tarmac, some of the noisiest records of the 1990s were hammered into shape.

Take a moment and look around you.
There’s the white townhouse – number 3 Abbey Road – with its neat sash windows. The studio sign by the door is oddly low-key, considering its reputation. Between you and the building: the zebra crossing. It looks like any other crossing in London, except this one had four Beatles walking across it in 1969, and now it has an endless procession of tourists trying not to get flattened by oncoming traffic.

Today though, we’re not here for the 1960s. We’re going to jump forward a few decades, to when another wave of British bands came here chasing something very specific: the sound, the prestige, and the ghosts of this place.

Before the parkas and the Britpop swagger, this was just a big house with a very expensive hobby.

The story starts in the 1830s, when this was built as a large Georgian villa, the sort of place you’d expect a respectable Victorian family to rattle around in. Fast-forward to the late 1920s, and the Gramophone Company – ancestors of EMI – buy it up. They keep the house at the front, then dig out the back garden and build enormous studio spaces behind it.

In 1931 they open what they call EMI Recording Studios with a show of confidence: Sir Edward Elgar conducting the London Symphony Orchestra in “Land of Hope and Glory” for the microphones. For decades it’s mainly classical, light orchestras, polite dance bands. Then the 1960s happen, the Beatles move into Studio Two, and everything changes.

By the time the 1990s roll around, Abbey Road is already mythical. This is the room where Revolver, Sgt Pepper and The Dark Side of the Moon were made. For a new generation of British guitar bands, that’s not just trivia – that’s a challenge.

So picture Britain in the early 90s: post-Thatcher hangover, Britpop starting to bubble up, guitar bands swaggering back onto Top of the Pops. You’ve got record labels looking for big, bold albums that can stand on the shelf next to the classics. And somewhere in a label meeting, someone says: “Well… why don’t we just book the same studio the Beatles used?”

Suddenly, this quiet street in St John’s Wood is on the itinerary for a very different cast of characters.

One of the earliest 90s bands to plug into the Abbey Road mythology is Radiohead. They’re not Britpop in the Union Jack-sofa sense, but they’re absolutely part of that guitar-band wave. Parts of The Bends are worked on here; later, strings and mastering for OK Computer use these rooms. You can imagine the contrast: skinny kids from Oxford stepping into Studio One, with its huge floor and high ceiling, and being handed the keys to an orchestra.

At the same time, the studios are rediscovering one of their superpowers: those lush, cinematic strings. If you ever wondered how 90s records by bands like Suede or Pulp ended up sounding so grand, so “film soundtrack”, well – that’s the Abbey Road effect. Classical heritage, rock attitude.

But for the full Britpop myth, we probably need to talk about the elephants in the room: Oasis.

First, the mid-90s excess. During the Be Here Now era, Oasis are at peak volume and peak confidence. The band shuttle between studios, and Abbey Road is one of the places where backing tracks are laid down. You can easily imagine the scene: flight cases trundling in, amps stacked in Studio Two, tea, cigarettes and the odd lager can parked on the mixing desk.

Then we jump to 2007. A slightly older, slightly more battered Oasis come back here to record what turns out to be their final studio album, Dig Out Your Soul. Once again, they’re in Studio Two – the same high, echoing space where the Beatles once pushed four-track tape machines to breaking point.

According to Noel Gallagher – and he very much frames it as one of his stories – there’s a hitch. U2 supposedly have the studio block-booked. In Noel’s telling, he marches in with a suitcase of cash and buys the sessions out from under them so Oasis can have the room instead.

Is that exactly how it went down? The paperwork is quieter than Noel’s version. But as a piece of Britpop folklore it’s perfect: a band so determined to sit in the Beatles’ chair that they’re prepared to outbid anyone else in the queue.

As those Dig Out Your Soul sessions roll on, this building becomes part of a closing chapter. The songs might not be as universally loved as the early hits, but this is effectively Oasis’ last stand in the studio – and it happens here, on this sleepy London street, in a room full of ghosts.

Now, shift your attention back to the street itself.

Look around you again.
Check out the low wall in front of the studios. It’s probably covered in scribbles – song lyrics, band logos, messages from fans who’ve saved up to make the pilgrimage. Every so often the wall gets repainted, and within days it’s layered with ink again: Beatles quotes, Oasis lyrics, Radiohead lines, declarations of love to bands that saved someone’s teenage years.

Out on the crossing, the scenes repeat in a loop. A group in Beatles haircuts, shuffling across in single file. Behind them, some 90s kids at heart, in Adidas and bucket hats, trying to channel their inner Gallagher for a phone camera. Locals roll their eyes; drivers tap the steering wheel and wait it out. For them, this is just the world’s most annoying pedestrian crossing. For the people flying in from the other side of the world, it’s a once-in-a-lifetime moment.

Inside, Abbey Road has had its own dramas. In the late 2000s, rumours surface that the studios might be sold off, maybe turned into luxury flats. Musicians, fans and locals kick up enough fuss that the building is granted protected status. The government literally lists a working recording studio as a piece of national heritage. Not bad for a place full of tangled cables and drum risers.

Today, the story hasn’t stopped. Big-name artists still come here to record. Orchestras still fill Studio One for film scores. New bands still walk up those steps hoping a little magic will rub off. And tourists – maybe including you, right now – still dodge traffic for a blurry shot in the middle of the road.

So as you stand here, between the studio door and the white stripes of the crossing, you’re in a kind of layered time warp. In one layer, it’s 1969 and four guys from Liverpool are about to take the most famous stroll in rock history. In another, it’s 1997 and a band from Manchester is dragging an entire culture along with them in a cloud of feedback and bravado. In another, a quiet, serious group from Oxford is tuning strings for a record that will define the decade.

You’re not inside the building, but you are on the threshold of all of that.

When you head off to the next stop, take a last glance back at the crossing and the studio sign. Every band we’re meeting on this Britpop journey had to step out of the safety of rooms like this and take their chances in the real world – on stage, on the radio, in the tabloids. Abbey Road is where the records got finished. The next place you’re going is where those records met the rest of us.

title: Enriqueta Rylands
inscription: Born in Havana in 1843, Enriqueta Rylands rose from orphaned merchant’s daughter to Manchester’s richest widow. Deeply religious and determined, she used her cotton-derived inheritance to create the neo-Gothic John Rylands Library on Deansgate, filling it with world-class collections and leaving a lasting, complicated legacy of faith, philanthropy and empire.
lead_subject_bio:
You’re standing in front of what looks like a small cathedral that got lost and ended up in the middle of Deansgate traffic.
Stone turrets, pointed arches, grim little faces peering down at you… it absolutely looks like a church.

It isn’t.
It’s a love letter – to a husband, to a city, and to the written word – signed by a woman most people have never heard of: Enriqueta Rylands.

Look around you for a moment.

Let your eyes run up the front of the building.
Notice the dark red stone, the traceried windows, the carved coats of arms, the initials tucked into the masonry. Then zoom back out to the street: buses, bikes, coffee shops, glass-fronted offices. When this place was built at the end of the 1800s, Deansgate was already noisy, dirty and crowded. Not the obvious home for delicate manuscripts.

But that was the point.

Enriqueta didn’t want a quiet college library hidden in a courtyard. She wanted a monumental “house of books” right in the thick of Manchester life – practically in the gutter with the tramlines and the coal dust. If the city had made its money in cotton warehouses and mills, she was going to plant a castle of culture right in the same soil.

So who on earth was she?

Enriqueta Augustina Tennant was born a long way from here, in Havana, in 1843. Her father was a British merchant, her mother from a French-American family. Their business world was sugar, tobacco, timber and cotton – the classic products of the 19th-century Americas, tangled up with plantations and empire.

By her early teens, both parents were gone. Enriqueta and her siblings were shipped to Britain to live with relatives. So imagine that: Havana heat swapped for North Atlantic drizzle; Spanish and French voices replaced with English; the security of home replaced with… well, something rather more precarious.

Fast-forward a few years and she turns up in this area of the world as a “companion” – something between lady-in-waiting and senior servant – to Martha Rylands, the second wife of Manchester’s great cotton magnate, John Rylands, out at Longford Hall in Stretford.

When Martha dies, the household is shaken. And then, a few months later, in one of those moments that set Victorian tongues wagging, thirty-two-year-old Enriqueta marries seventy-four-year-old John.

The age gap is huge. The gossip writes itself.
Neighbours mutter about money and ambition; later writers have had fun with the idea of the young companion marrying the old millionaire.

What we can actually see in the record is a little more complex. Both were deeply religious in a sober, Nonconformist way. Both believed that wealth came with a duty to do good. And whatever the exact emotional chemistry, the marriage placed Enriqueta in a position the girl from Havana could probably never have imagined.

When John dies in 1888, she inherits the bulk of his fortune. In today’s money, we’re talking hundreds of millions of pounds. Enough to buy yourself several small countries. Or, as it turned out, one very remarkable library.

She could have retired quietly to a seaside villa and commissioned the odd charitable plaque. Instead, she goes shopping for land and rare books.

In 1889 she buys this awkward, cramped plot on Deansgate – hemmed in by other buildings, expensive, polluted – and hires architect Basil Champneys to create something extraordinary. She doesn’t just sign the cheques and disappear. She pores over plans. She argues about details. She chooses themes for the stained glass. She even negotiates with the neighbours about how high their buildings can be, to protect the light.

Champneys designs a neo-Gothic masterpiece. Enriqueta, according to more than one architect’s polite memoir, is not shy about saying what she wants changed. He imagines one scheme of decoration; she insists on another. The result is what you see in front of you: a stone sermon on the seriousness of books.

In a moment, when you step inside, you’ll climb a flight of stone stairs, the traffic noise will fade, and you’ll emerge into the historic reading room. It’s long and high like a nave, with a vaulted ceiling and big windows at either end. At one end stands a marble John, at the other a marble Enriqueta, watching over a central “aisle” of desks as if they were pews.

Take that interior in when you get there – it’s your second “look around you” moment.

Notice how the windows aren’t just pretty colours. In one direction, the glass is filled with theologians and church figures; in the other, with writers, scholars and artists. That’s very Enriqueta: faith and literature in the same visual breath. For her, books were not just entertainment. They were part of a moral and spiritual education.

And in amongst the ribbed stone and medieval mood, remember this was one of the first public buildings in Manchester to be lit by electricity. Underneath the Gothic drama, there was very modern wiring. It’s like the building itself is saying: “We may be dressed in the Middle Ages, but we’re very much a machine of the industrial age.”

Of course, a beautiful container is only half the story. What she does next is fill it.

Quietly, almost secretly, she buys one of the great private book collections of Europe – the Spencer Collection – at enormous cost. Early printed books, treasures of the first age of printing. She adds more: medieval manuscripts, archives, devotional works, scientific texts. Later, the library acquires things so rare they’re almost mythical – a Gutenberg Bible, and a tiny scrap of papyrus, no bigger than a credit card, bearing a few lines from the Gospel of John, which scholars think may be the earliest surviving fragment of the New Testament.

When you’re inside, if you visit the exhibitions, you’ll be able to stand over a glass case and look down at that little brown scrap, and realise it’s older than Manchester by nearly two thousand years.

All of this – the wonders in the cases, the carved stone above your head, the city’s most atmospheric study space – rests on money made from cotton and colonial trade. Enriqueta’s childhood in Havana, John’s mills and warehouses around here: they were all part of a global system that relied on the labour of people with far fewer choices than the readers who walked into this library in 1900.

That’s the uncomfortable shadow that falls across the beauty of the place.
But it’s also part of why the story is so powerful: a fortune made in an unequal world turned into an institution that tried, in its own way, to open knowledge to more than just the elite.

When the library was formally dedicated, the city of Manchester did something it had never done before. It made Enriqueta Rylands the first woman to receive the Freedom of the City. A Cuban-born orphan, once a companion in someone else’s household, was suddenly at the civic centre of things – with a building that would outlive all of them.

So as you stand here, between the traffic and the turrets, you’re right on the fault line between those histories: empire and philanthropy, industry and ideas, the anonymous labour of the mills and the famous names on the spines of books.

In a moment, head inside. Climb the stairs, step into the reading room, find the statues at either end, and give Enriqueta a nod as you walk past. Manchester is full of grand buildings funded by powerful men. This one exists because one woman refused to stay in the background – and decided that, if the city was going to have temples, at least one of them should be built for readers.

title: Elizabeth Raffald
inscription: If you’ve ever cut into a rich fruit wedding cake under a layer of white icing, you might owe thanks to a woman who once ran a coaching inn right under your feet. Before Marks & Spencer, this corner of Manchester belonged to Elizabeth Raffald – cook, landlady, publisher, and all-round business whirlwind.
lead_subject_bio:
You’re standing outside a busy Marks & Spencer, watching trams slide past and shoppers weave around each other. It all feels very 21st century – glass, adverts, coffee cups. But if you could peel back a couple of centuries of brick and tarmac, you’d be standing in the tap-room of a noisy coaching inn called the Bull’s Head. Smoke, horses, gossip – and, in the middle of it all, a woman called Elizabeth Raffald, running half a dozen businesses at once.

If you’ve ever cut into a rich fruit wedding cake under a layer of white icing, you may well have tasted her legacy. The woman who helped shape that tradition, wrote a bestselling cookbook, and published Manchester’s first trade directory once worked right here, beneath your feet.

Take a moment and look around you. Picture this block not as a shopping street but as Manchester’s old Market Place. Forget the plate glass: imagine hanging signboards creaking above doorways, carts piled with vegetables and cheese, the rattle of carriage wheels on cobbles. Where you see shopfronts and window displays now, picture the frontage of a coaching inn – the Bull’s Head – with smoke rising from chimneys and the smell of beer and roasting meat drifting out into the street.

In the 1760s, this was Elizabeth Raffald’s world.

She didn’t start here. Elizabeth was born in Doncaster in the 1730s and spent much of her early life in domestic service. Her big break came when she became housekeeper at Arley Hall in Cheshire – a kind of chief operating officer for a grand country house. She oversaw kitchens, stores, staff, and the endless stream of meals and entertainments demanded by a wealthy family. By the time she married the head gardener, John Raffald, she’d clocked up more than a decade of hard, practical experience.

When the couple left service and moved to Manchester, they weren’t starting from nothing. They brought serious skills… and good timing. Manchester was changing from market town to industrial powerhouse. The town was filling up with merchants, professionals and ambitious families, all hungry – literally – for a more refined way of eating and living.

At first, Elizabeth set up a confectionery and catering business near here, close to the market. Picture a small but elegant shop: the windows crowded with jellies, sugar sculptures, iced creams, delicate pastries, and imported delicacies. Inside, you’d find not just sweets but also savouries, pickles and preserved foods – the kind of things that made a Georgian dinner table look impressive.

She didn’t stop at selling food. From the same premises she ran a register office – an early employment agency – matching servants to households. She gave cookery lessons. Her husband sold seeds and plants. If LinkedIn had existed, her profile would have been terrifying.

As her reputation grew, so did her ambitions. Which brings us back to this spot.

At the height of her success, Elizabeth and John took on the Bull’s Head, a busy coaching inn standing right here in the old Market Place. This wasn’t a sleepy country pub. It was a hub. Coaches clattered in and out, carrying passengers and letters. Travellers needed beds and hot meals at odd hours. Local merchants needed private rooms for meetings and banquets. The Bull’s Head was where the town’s business and gossip mixed.

Step back from the present for a moment and look around you again. Try to map today’s scene onto the 18th century. The stream of people with shopping bags becomes a line of coach passengers hurrying to catch their ride. That side street becomes the entrance to a yard where horses are being harnessed. Somewhere in this block, someone is hauling barrels into a cellar; upstairs, candles are being lit in a panelled dining room where a long table is set with pewter plates and cut crystal.

In the middle of all this, imagine Elizabeth Raffald: taking orders, managing staff, planning menus for grand dinners and improvised suppers, juggling the accounts and the timetable for coaches and post. From this one operation she ran a tap-room, an inn, a post office, a carriage-hire business and a catering service. Modern “serial entrepreneur” doesn’t quite cover it.

But her most lasting influence didn’t come from the inn’s kitchen alone – it came from a book she wrote there.

In 1769, Elizabeth published The Experienced English Housekeeper, a substantial cookery book based, as she put it, “purely from practice”. That phrase is key. Unlike some earlier recipe collections, this wasn’t a vague list of dishes for people who already knew what they were doing. She gave clear instructions, measurements, and full menus. She explained how to organise a household’s food, not just how to throw a dish together.

Hidden among the hundreds of recipes is one that changed British celebrations: her “Bride Cake”. It’s a dense fruit cake soaked in spirits, dressed first in almond paste and then in smooth white icing. Sounds familiar? That combination is a direct ancestor of the traditional British wedding cake – the one people still cut today for photographs. The idea that such ceremonies should feature a grand, white-iced cake owes a lot to the woman who once managed this inn.

Her book was a runaway hit. It went through numerous editions and was pirated enthusiastically. Eventually she sold the rights for a large lump sum – a risky but bold move in a world where female authors were hardly guaranteed respect, let alone profit.

And then she did something that shaped Manchester in a more literal way. She turned from kitchens to streets.

In the early 1770s, Elizabeth produced Manchester and Salford’s first trade directory. Think of it as an 18th-century Yellow Pages: a listing of businesses and professionals, addresses, trades and services. To compile it, she had to get under the skin of the town – who was where, doing what, on which street. It helped impose order on a fast-growing place whose streets and businesses were still in flux.

Ironically, it’s partly thanks to that sort of record-keeping that we can say with confidence that the Bull’s Head was here, and that she was running so much from it.

Her story, though, isn’t a neat success-only tale. She and John had a large family – how large exactly depends on which source you trust. Parish records show several daughters; later storytellers inflate the number until it sounds almost impossible. The same thing happens with rumours about her later life: some tales say she practised midwifery, or even dabbled in exorcising spirits. Those make good fireside stories, but they’re much harder to pin down than her very real invoices, recipes and directories.

We do know that despite the money her book earned, much of her fortune slipped away in later years, possibly through business risks that didn’t pay off. She died suddenly in 1781, her name not even added to the family tombstone in Stockport. For a long time, her story faded, while another Victorian compiler of recipes – Mrs Beeton, who borrowed from earlier writers like Raffald – became the household name.

So as you stand here now, outside a modern department store, remember that this apparently ordinary corner was once the command centre of someone extraordinary. A former servant who turned experience into expertise, expertise into business, and business into books that shaped how people across Britain cooked, ate, and celebrated.

Manchester likes to see itself as a city of self-made people, a place where outsiders come to reinvent themselves and, if they’re determined enough, leave a mark on the wider world. Elizabeth Raffald did exactly that. Her inn may be gone, its rooms buried under layers of brick, concrete and retail design, but her recipes, her directories and her quiet revolution in everyday life are still with you – perhaps even in the next slice of wedding cake you eat.

title: Emmeline Pankhurst
inscription: But a little over a century ago, this might have been the most alarming front parlour in Manchester – at least if you were a politician who thought women should sit quietly, pay their taxes, and leave the voting to men. Because behind this doorway, in No. 62 Nelson Street, a handful of women met and decided to change the rules of British democracy… by force, if necessary.
address: The Pankhurst Centre, 60–62 Nelson Street, Chorlton-on-Medlock, M13 9WP
lead_subject_bio:
You’re standing outside a perfectly ordinary red-brick house, tucked between big modern hospital blocks and university buildings.
From the pavement, it doesn’t look especially dangerous.

But a little over a century ago, this might have been the most alarming front parlour in Manchester – at least if you were a politician who thought women should sit quietly, pay their taxes, and leave the voting to men. Because behind this doorway, in No. 62 Nelson Street, a handful of women met and decided to change the rules of British democracy… by force, if necessary.

This is the Pankhurst Centre – and this is where the suffragette movement was born.

Take a moment to look around you.

Notice how modest the house is: two narrow brick villas, a tiny strip of front garden, iron railings, a blue plaque on the wall. Once, Nelson Street ran as a whole row of homes like this, a respectable middle-class suburb just off Oxford Road. Almost all of it has gone – cleared for roads, car parks and hospitals.

What you’re seeing is a scrap of a vanished neighbourhood, a little time capsule wedged into modern Manchester. And somehow, this unassuming front door became the entrance to a political earthquake.

Step closer in your mind, whether you’re standing at the railings outside or inside in the compact front parlour itself.

Picture the house at the end of the 19th century. Emmeline Pankhurst lives here with her children. She was born not far away in Moss Side and raised on a diet of politics – anti-slavery meetings, talk of women’s rights, the whole radical Manchester package. She married Richard Pankhurst, a lawyer famous for drafting early women’s suffrage bills and laws letting married women control their own property.

By the time she moves into this house, Richard is dead. Emmeline is a widowed mother, still fiercely political, but now also holding down a job as the local Registrar of Births and Deaths.

It sounds dry. It isn’t.

Day after day, women come to her desk from the streets around here. She records babies who don’t live to see their first birthday. Women exhausted by too many pregnancies in too few years. Young women whose deaths are recorded in careful ink but whose choices in life were almost non-existent. She sees, up close, how little power they have over their bodies, their money, their futures.

If you imagine her sitting at a small desk somewhere inside this very house, squinting over those ledgers by gaslight, you can see why “waiting patiently” was never going to be her long-term strategy.

Now imagine the evening that changes everything.

It’s 1903. In the front parlour – the room that’s been recreated inside the museum – a small group of women are gathered. Chairs pulled close, hats and gloves off, the fire ticking quietly in the grate. Outside, Nelson Street is dark and still; inside, Emmeline is furious.

For decades, polite suffrage societies have written letters, hosted meetings, gathered signatures. Parliament has nodded, smiled, and done very little. Emmeline has had enough.

Here, in this room, she proposes something new: a women-only organisation that will concentrate entirely on winning the vote – and that will be prepared to break the rules to get it. They call it the Women’s Social and Political Union. You’ll know it by its initials: WSPU.

Their motto is short and blunt: “Deeds, not words.”

At this point they have no banners, no famous colours, no marches – just a decision in a cramped parlour on a back street. They also have no idea that a London newspaper is about to invent a new word for them. The Daily Mail will try to belittle these campaigners as “suffragettes” – the “-ette” suggesting they’re cute, childish, not to be taken seriously. The women promptly adopt it as a badge of honour. If being a suffragette means being a troublemaker, they’re in.

And trouble is exactly what follows.

Within a few years, the WSPU outgrows this little parlour and spreads out across Manchester, London and beyond. Their tactics escalate. At first they disrupt political meetings, heckle cabinet ministers, and stage dramatic protests. When that fails to budge Parliament, they move on to smashing windows, attacking post boxes, setting fire to empty buildings and golf greens.

Emmeline Pankhurst becomes the public face of this militancy. She’s arrested repeatedly. In prison, she and her comrades go on hunger strike; the authorities answer with force-feeding, an ordeal that leaves some women permanently injured.

To their supporters, these women are heroes. To much of the establishment, they’re vandals, extremists – sometimes described in language not a million miles from “terrorist”.

Even today, historians argue over whether this kind of militancy helped force change by making the old system untenable, or whether it frightened potential supporters and slowed everything down. What’s not in doubt is that it kept women’s suffrage on the front pages, and it all traces back to that decision in this front room.

The drama isn’t only on the streets; it’s also inside the family.

Emmeline’s daughters – Christabel, Sylvia and Adela – all throw themselves into the cause. For a while, it looks like the Pankhursts are a tight-knit revolutionary dynasty. But behind closed doors, arguments erupt: over how militant to be, over class politics, over the looming question of war.

Sylvia wants a more socialist, working-class movement. Adela is more radical still. Emmeline and Christabel want a tight, centrally controlled organisation with a single message. Eventually, the splits become so bitter that Emmeline effectively packs Adela off to Australia with a one-way ticket.

In a house dedicated to equality, decisions at the kitchen table could be anything but democratic.

Then war breaks out in 1914, and the movement takes another sharp turn.

Emmeline suspends militant suffrage action and throws herself into the war effort, urging women to take up war work and men to enlist. Some of her former allies see this as a betrayal of pacifist principles. Others argue she’s seizing a brutal opportunity: if women keep the country running during war, how can anyone deny them a say in peace?

By 1918, Parliament blinks. A new law gives the vote to most men over 21 and to women over 30 who meet certain property or qualification rules. It’s not equality – younger and poorer women are still excluded – but it’s a crack in the door.

Ten years later, in 1928, that door is finally flung open: women win the vote on the same terms as men, at 21. Emmeline Pankhurst dies just weeks before the law takes effect. She lives long enough to see the future coming, not quite long enough to stand in a queue with a ballot paper in her hand.

And what about this house after she leaves it?

For much of the 20th century, the area around you declines. The old terraces become lodging houses and slums. Big swathes of Nelson Street are demolished for road schemes and medical buildings. At various points, these two houses are derelict, boarded up, pencilled in for clearance.

Then, once again, women refuse to accept the inevitable. Local campaigners, feminist groups, historians and neighbours push to save 60–62 Nelson Street as the birthplace of the suffragette movement. After a long fight, they succeed. The buildings are restored and turned into what you see today: the Pankhurst Centre.

Now, look around you again.

If you step inside, you’ll find the front parlour dressed to evoke that 1903 meeting: a small fireplace, simple chairs, a sense that you could push the furniture back a little and begin plotting. In other rooms, displays tell the story of Emmeline and her comrades – but you might also notice something else on the doors: the name Manchester Women’s Aid.

The same front door that once opened to women planning arson attacks on post boxes now opens to women escaping violent homes, and to those supporting them. The struggle here has shifted from the right to vote to the right to live safely and independently, but the thread is easy to trace: who gets power, who has a voice, who is believed.

From the pavement, it’s still just a modest red-brick terrace. From the inside, it’s the place where a handful of angry, determined women decided that “being patient” had gone on quite long enough – and set out to rewrite the rules.

As you head away from Nelson Street and back towards the heart of Manchester, keep an eye on the plaques and statues, the names on buildings and squares. This city has a habit of turning its troublemakers into landmarks. Emmeline started in a cramped parlour on a fading side street. Today, every time you step into a polling booth, you’re walking in her footsteps – whether you knew her name or not.

title: Mary Fildes and the Women of Peterloo
inscription: This is where, in August 1819, around sixty thousand people gathered for a peaceful meeting to demand a fairer political system – and where cavalry were sent in with sabres drawn. We remember that day as the Peterloo Massacre.
address: Peterloo Memorial, St Peter’s Square, Windmill St,M2 3DW
lead_subject_bio:
You’re standing on what used to be called St Peter’s Field – though it doesn’t look much like a field now, does it?

Trams glide past, glass offices reflect the sky, and there’s probably someone nearby juggling a coffee and a phone call. It all feels very ordinary… which makes it hard to picture the day this calm space turned into one of the most notorious scenes of political violence in British history.

This is where, in August 1819, around sixty thousand people gathered for a peaceful meeting to demand a fairer political system – and where cavalry were sent in with sabres drawn. We remember that day as the Peterloo Massacre.

At the very centre of it all was a woman: Mary Fildes. President of the Manchester Female Reform Society, mother of eight, grocer’s daughter… and, on that afternoon, one of the most visible – and most vulnerable – people on the field.

Look around you for a moment.

Find the Peterloo Memorial – the circular stack of stone steps that looks a bit like a layered cake, or a miniature amphitheatre. If you’re close enough, you might see words carved into the rings: the names of the dead, and the towns and villages they walked from to be here.

Now try, just for a second, to scrub away the trams and the offices. Imagine this space as an open, dusty field on a hot August day. No cars. No tracks. Just people. Tens of thousands of them. Families in their Sunday best, bands playing, flags and banners fluttering above the crowd.

They’ve come because life in 1819 is hard and unfair. The wars with France are over, but the peace hasn’t brought prosperity. Food is expensive, work is uncertain, and thanks to the Corn Laws, bread stays stubbornly out of reach for many. Manchester is booming with cotton mills, but it barely has a voice in Parliament. Most adults – including all women – can’t vote at all.

So people turn up here for a legal, peaceful meeting to demand parliamentary reform. They’ve been told to come “orderly and peaceable”, and they do. They bring children. They carry picnic baskets. This is meant to be a show of respectability, not a riot.

And into this crowd marches a new and unsettling presence: women, organised as political actors in their own right.

Mary Fildes is one of them. She wasn’t born into power or privilege. She grew up in a grocer’s family, married a reed-maker, and raised eight children. But if you look at the names she gives those children – Thomas Paine, Henry Hunt, John Cartwright – you get a sense of what fires her up. She’s steeped in the language of rights and reform.

In the summer of 1819 she becomes president of the newly formed Manchester Female Reform Society. This isn’t a sewing circle with opinions; it’s a political organisation. The women hold meetings, draft addresses, send messages to famous radicals and even to the Queen. And today, they turn out in force.

Picture them as they approach St Peter’s Field: many of them dressed in white, marching together behind their own banner, a striking block of movement in the sea of people. Some are here with husbands and children, others with neighbours from their mill or their street. They’re not background decoration; they are a key part of the spectacle.

Mary rides in at the front of the procession in the same carriage as the main speaker, Henry Hunt. The plan is for her to present him with a cap of liberty and the women’s colours – a very deliberate echo of revolutionary rituals, transplanted to a Lancashire field.

To their supporters, these women are respectable, serious, morally powerful. To their enemies, they are shocking: “unfeminine”, dangerous, the subject of sneering cartoons in the conservative press. Women, in public, demanding politics. For some magistrates watching from the windows nearby, that’s almost as disturbing as the size of the crowd itself.

Up on the wooden platform in the middle of the field – the hustings – Mary stands beside Hunt and the other speakers. Below them, the crowd is packed shoulder to shoulder. There are so many people that if you dropped something, you’d struggle to bend down and pick it up again.

In the houses around the edge of the field, local magistrates peer out from upstairs rooms. They are nervous, suspicious, and frankly hostile. They sign an order to arrest Hunt and break up the meeting. Then they send in the Manchester and Salford Yeomanry – part-time mounted volunteers – to do it.

Imagine the moment when the mood changes.

One minute there’s music and cheering. The next, you hear the sudden drumming of hooves. Riders force their way into the crowd, sabres out. Flags are slashed down. People are knocked over, trampled, cut.

Women in white dresses, so visible moments ago, become painfully easy targets in the crush.

On the hustings, Mary sees the cavalry and constables fighting their way towards the platform. As she tries to escape, she’s dragged down. Later, in a sworn statement, she describes a special constable striking her again and again with a heavy truncheon as she lies on the ground, and how she narrowly avoids a sabre blow that could have killed her. She’s beaten so badly she can’t leave her room for more than a fortnight.

Elsewhere on the field, other women are sabred, ridden down, or crushed. A pregnant mother later dies after a premature birth blamed on her injuries. A young woman is killed by a sabre cut to the head. When historians add up the casualty lists, they notice something striking: women make up a relatively small part of the crowd, but a much larger share of the injured. Many eyewitnesses at the time believed the troops singled them out.

And the violence doesn’t begin or end here on the field. The first person to die because of Peterloo is a two-year-old boy, William Fildes, thrown from his mother’s arms and fatally injured as cavalry ride through the streets on their way to the meeting. He never even reaches the crowd.

After the dust settles, the authorities insist they’ve saved the town from insurrection. Reformers insist the state has butchered its own citizens. The press argue, pamphlets fly, and the government doubles down with new “gagging acts” to clamp down on radical meetings.

Mary, recovering from her injuries, doesn’t vanish into private life. She keeps speaking at political gatherings in the years that follow, turning up in reports of reform and later Chartist meetings. At home, in quieter moments, she helps raise her grandson Luke and uses a small inheritance to pay for his art lessons. He grows up to be Sir Luke Fildes, a celebrated Victorian painter whose work hangs in major galleries.

It’s an unexpected legacy: the woman beaten on the hustings helps launch one of the great artists of the age.

Now, look around you again.

Look at the memorial steps. Look at the names and the place-names carved into the stone – a map of the region’s anger and hope in 1819. Look at people sitting, chatting, scrolling on their phones on a monument that was designed not just to be seen, but to be climbed, stood on, spoken from.

It wasn’t always like this. For a long time, Peterloo was marked only by modest plaques, and even those took effort to put up. Only in 2019, two centuries after the massacre, did Manchester finally unveil this large, central memorial.

And even then, there was an argument. The stepped design means some people – wheelchair users, and others with mobility difficulties – can’t easily get onto the upper levels. A memorial to democracy and equality that some citizens can’t fully access: an uncomfortable irony that disability campaigners were quick to point out.

The council has since admitted it “got it wrong” and talked about ways to improve access. But in a way, that argument is part of the story. Peterloo has always been about who gets to stand in public, to be counted, to be heard.

Mary Fildes didn’t live to see universal suffrage. She never got a vote herself. But she showed that women in the cotton towns of the north could organise, speak, and refuse to stay in the background – even when the price was paid in blood.

The fact that you can stand here today, listening openly to her story in the middle of the city, is part of what she and tens of thousands of others were asking for: not perfection, but a public voice.

When you leave this spot and head to your next stop, carry that with you: beneath Manchester’s streets and tramlines, there’s a memory of women in white dresses and men with sabres, arguing – in the most brutal way possible – about who counts in a democracy. And that argument isn’t as distant from us as the old field might make it seem.

title: Women of Back Pool Fold
inscription: In this gloomy service alley, women were once paraded, strapped to a chair, and plunged into a pond for talking too much, answering back, or having the wrong kind of sex.
address: The Fold, 3 Back Pool Fold, M2 1HB
lead_subject_bio:
You’re standing in what looks like the scruffy back end of the city – bins, pipes, the service doors of cafés and offices. If your phone battery died right now, you’d never guess this was a “place of interest”. It’s just a shortcut.

But for a long time, this alley was something else. This was a stage. And the star performers were women the city wanted to shame.

First, take a moment and look around you.

Notice how narrow this passage is. The high brick walls, the fire escapes, the tangle of ducting overhead. Now, mentally drain away the tarmac and paving under your feet. In its place, imagine a stretch of dark, stagnant water: the moat or pond that once sat behind a grand house called Radcliffe Hall, on Pool Fold – now lost under shops and offices.

Back then, this wouldn’t have felt like a handy cut-through. It would have felt like the edge of something: the back of a lake, a boundary where decent town gave way to mud, rubbish and punishment.

That’s the “pool” in Back Pool Fold – the rear of a body of water that once ran from the lower end of Market Street round to somewhere near where you’re standing now. The big house faced the pool; this lane clung to its back. Over time, Pool Fold was absorbed into the wider Cross Street. The fancy frontage was tidied up and modernised. But this little dog-leg of a passage survived, fossilising the old boundary line.

And right on the edge of that murky water, the town set up something special: a ducking stool.

A ducking stool sounds almost comical until you picture it properly.

Imagine a solid wooden chair fixed to the end of a long beam, like a giant seesaw gone wrong. The beam pivots on a frame at the water’s edge. A woman – usually a woman – is tied into the chair. The beam is swung out over the pond. And then, with a nice clear view for the crowd, she’s dropped in. Up. Down. Up. Down. As many times as the magistrates – or the mood of the mob – decides.

Who ended up in that chair?

On paper, it was for “common scolds”: women accused of nagging, shouting abuse, disturbing the peace. In practice, it caught all sorts: street traders who answered back, neighbours caught in noisy feuds, sex workers, women who had the bad timing to become visibly pregnant without a husband.

Every so often, a dishonest male tradesman might find himself strapped in too, but make no mistake – this was widely understood as a women’s punishment. It wasn’t just about crime. It was about control.

We can’t point to a stone here and say, “The stool was exactly there.” The pond’s long gone, and the details weren’t drawn on a nice town plan for us. What we do have are local histories, an antiquarian sketch, and a modern plaque that all agree: Manchester’s ducking stool stood in the moat or pool that once reached right up to this alley.

So when you stand here, you’re on the dry ghost of that waterline.

For a minute, let’s walk this through from her point of view.

The woman we’re thinking about doesn’t have a name in the records, so we won’t give her one. That keeps us honest. But we know her type. She might be a market woman who shouts too loudly at customers, or a servant who’s accused her master of something he’d rather not have repeated. Maybe she’s pregnant and not married, and someone has decided that shame should be a public event.

She’s been hauled before the local officials, formally declared a scold or “lewd”, and sentenced to the ducking stool. There’s no privacy in this. The whole point is that everyone sees.

She’s walked through the streets towards Pool Fold. People peel off from their errands and follow. Children tug at sleeves. Someone runs ahead to get a good view. By the time she arrives at the water’s edge, there’s a small crowd jostling for position.

She sees the chair. It’s rough, splintered, damp from the last person who sat there. She’s tied in – hands, waist, maybe even shoulders. All those faces staring, some angry, some amused, some just glad it’s not them.

The beam creaks. For a moment she’s hanging out over the water, suspended. Then the men at the pivot let her drop.

The pond that once lay here wouldn’t have been clean. Think drainage, refuse, animal waste – everything that a growing, industrialising town wanted to push to the edges. The shock of the cold hits her chest. The stink hits the back of her throat. She comes up choking to the sound of laughter or jeers.

And then, because this is the whole point, they do it again.

This isn’t really about whether she “deserves” it. It’s about everybody watching learning what happens to women who speak too loudly, complain too much, or live in a way that makes neighbours uncomfortable.

Now, bring yourself back to the present and look around you again.

See how the lane kinks and narrows, like it’s skirting around something that isn’t there anymore. Look towards Cross Street, where the buildings open out into the flow of modern Manchester. Somewhere along this line, between where you’re standing and the busier street ahead, that ducking beam once jutted out over the water.

If there’s a plaque here when you visit, take a second to read it. It’s small, easily missed, but it quietly admits that this tucked-away service alley was once part of the city’s machinery of punishment.

Then glance towards the corner where Sam’s Chop House now offers warm lights and full plates. One of Manchester’s favourite Victorian pubs, with a bronze L.S. Lowry propping up the bar inside, looking permanently melancholy over his pint. It’s an oddly cosy neighbour for such a grim story.

Ducking stools fell out of use in Britain in the 18th and early 19th centuries. Reformers began to see them as barbaric, out of step with a more “civilised” idea of justice. Elsewhere in the country, they were literally taken down and put into museums as curiosities – the sort of thing people pointed at and said, “Can you believe we used to do that?”

But the attitudes behind them – the urge to police who gets to speak, who gets to take up space, whose sexuality is acceptable – didn’t vanish with the timber. They just changed tactics.

Historians now talk about ducking stools as part of a wider toolkit aimed squarely at women: witch trials, slander suits, social ostracism. All different ways of saying: “Know your place. Know when to be quiet.”

And that’s what makes this alley more than just a bit of quirky local colour. It’s a scar from that system, hidden in the street plan.

As you get ready to move on, hold onto one thought.

Most plaques in cities like Manchester celebrate individuals: a famous scientist, a notable mayor, a beloved artist. Here, we have almost the opposite: a reminder of people whose names we don’t know, whose stories were never written down, but whose lives were violently interrupted right where you’re standing.

So the next time you cut down a grim little back street like this, don’t be too quick to dismiss it as nothing. It might be the last surviving edge of a lost pond. It might be where your city once chose to make an example of someone. It might be one of the few places where the past whispers, not through a grand statue, but through the shape of the ground and the memory of those whose voices were pushed under the surface.

From here, as you head back out towards Cross Street, you’re also walking forwards in time – towards other parts of Manchester where women fought to be heard, not ducked. Different streets, different tactics. Same question: who gets to speak, and who gets pushed under?

title: Hannah Beswick
inscription: Ghosts at Birchin Bower, tales of gold under flagstones and mystery coffins – how stories rush in to fill the gaps when someone’s body and burial don’t follow the usual script.
lead_subject_bio:
You’re standing on Oxford Road, facing the stone façade of Manchester Museum – all arches, towers and carved detail. It looks solid, respectable… the kind of place that’s always been here and always will be.

Now imagine walking through those doors in the 1830s and finding, among all the stuffed animals and fossils, the preserved body of a local woman who flatly refused to stay in the grave.

Or so the story goes.

For more than a century, the people of Manchester knew her as “the Manchester Mummy”. Her real name was Hannah Beswick – a wealthy 18th-century heiress who died in 1758 and wasn’t buried until 1868. In between, she spent decades upright in a doctor’s hallway, and then years on show in the museum that would eventually become the one in front of you.

Before we get to the clock case and the ghost stories, let’s set the scene.

Take a moment to look around you.

Notice how confident this building is: the pointed arches, the heavy stone, the sense that knowledge should be monumental. This was Victorian Manchester telling the world that industry and science lived here – not just cotton mills, but laboratories, lecture halls and cabinets of curiosities.

Inside today you’d find dinosaur skeletons, ancient artefacts and Egyptian mummies. In the 19th century, visitors would have seen something even stranger: a mummified woman from just up the road in Hollinwood, a few miles out of town. Not an ancient Egyptian princess – a local spinster.

Her story starts a long way from these Gothic towers, in 1688.

Hannah Beswick was born into a prosperous family at Cheetwood Old Hall, just north of Manchester. The Beswicks did well out of land and business; by the time her father died, Hannah had a comfortable income and a share in several properties, including a house called Birchin Bower near Oldham. She never married, which in that period often meant less social status – but in Hannah’s case also meant she kept control of her money.

Somewhere in the background of her life is a story that later generations couldn’t let go of. According to family lore, her brother John fell ill, was laid out for burial… and then, just as the coffin was about to be closed, he stirred. The story goes that he’d been wrongly declared dead and revived at the last moment.

We can’t prove that happened; there’s no nice neat medical report to back it up. But it’s the kind of tale that sticks. In Georgian England, fear of being buried alive was very real. Newspapers ran lurid stories, pamphlets proposed inventive “tests for life”, and inventors later dreamt up “safety coffins” with bells and flags in case you woke up six feet under.

Whether or not Hannah’s brother really opened his eyes on the brink of burial, people came to believe that this experience left her terrified of the grave.

Here’s where myth and paperwork collide.

In 1757, a year before her death, Hannah made her will. Later storytellers claimed she left a vast fortune to her doctor, on condition that he never let her be buried. The popular version has her begging him to keep checking that she was really dead.

It’s a powerful image – and almost certainly wrong.

The surviving will is a much duller document. It leaves her doctor a modest legacy and sets aside money for funeral expenses, but it doesn’t say, “Please embalm me, keep me above ground and show me off to your friends.” There’s no dramatic clause about being examined at intervals or stored in a clock.

And yet, that is more or less what happened.

When Hannah died in 1758, her physician was one of Manchester’s most prominent doctors: Charles White. White was a brilliant surgeon and a pioneer of obstetrics. He was also, by modern standards, a compulsive collector of body parts. His home was full of skeletons, preserved organs and anatomical specimens used for teaching.

Instead of giving Hannah a conventional burial, White had her embalmed. The exact method isn’t recorded, but it probably involved replacing her blood with preserving fluids and drying the body until it darkened and shrank. One description later said she was about four and a half feet tall and “the colour of mahogany”.

Rather than burying her, White kept her.

For years, visitors to his house in Sale were shown a long-case clock in which, it was said, Hannah’s mummified body stood upright. Picture it: you come for tea with a famous doctor and, between the anatomical models and the medical texts, you’re invited to meet “the Manchester Mummy” in the hallway.

Whatever Hannah’s wishes had really been, her body had become part medical specimen, part party piece.

After White’s death, his collections – including Hannah – passed to another doctor, and eventually to the Manchester Natural History Society. In 1835, when that society opened its museum, Hannah took up residence in a new home.

Now imagine stepping through the doors of this building’s predecessor.

Here’s your second look around you moment. As you stare at the stone front of the modern museum, try to picture an earlier entrance hall: glass cases packed with stuffed birds, shells and fossils, two Egyptian mummies lying in their painted coffins… and, beside them, a much smaller mummy, labelled as a woman from Birchin Bower, Hollinwood.

Her relatives were reportedly allowed free admission to visit her whenever they liked. “Visiting Aunt Hannah” acquired quite a different meaning.

For decades she stood there, a curiosity in the city’s front room. Guidebooks mentioned her. Children were brought to see her. She was, in her way, a minor celebrity.

By the 1860s, attitudes were changing. Manchester was bigger, smokier, more regulated. Laws about death and burial had tightened. The museum’s directors looked at this 18th-century mummy and decided it was time to lay her to rest.

There was a problem. Official death registration had only begun in 1837. Hannah had died almost eighty years earlier. On paper, as far as Victorian bureaucracy was concerned, she didn’t quite exist.

It took petitions to the Home Office and the blessing of the Bishop of Manchester to resolve the situation. Officials eventually agreed that a woman who’d been standing in a glass case for decades was, indeed, “irrevocably and unmistakably dead”.

In 1868, more than a hundred years after her death, Hannah Beswick was quietly buried in an unmarked grave in Harpurhey Cemetery. No gravestone, no grand memorial. Just a line in a register.

Of course, that wasn’t quite the end.

Back at Birchin Bower, the house she’d once lived in, stories were already taking root. One tale said that during the Jacobite rising of 1745, Hannah hid a hoard of gold coins under a flagstone to keep them safe from raiding soldiers. After her death, the location was lost – until, years later, a weaver digging a pit for his loom supposedly struck the very spot and found the coins.

Another story told of a woman in a black silk dress and white cap gliding across the parlour and vanishing at a particular flagstone. Locals decided it was Hannah, still guarding her gold.

These are stories, not court records. But they show how, when someone’s body never gets a normal burial, the imagination does the rest. Hannah ended up with three afterlives: as a person, as a specimen, and as a ghost.

Today, if you walk into Manchester Museum, you won’t find her. Her body isn’t on display. What survives is her will, a scattering of descriptions, some newspaper reports, and a lot of legend. The museum now spends a great deal of time thinking about how – and whether – to display human remains at all. Ancient mummies, skeletons, even medical specimens are treated more cautiously, with more emphasis on consent and respect.

Hannah’s story sits right at the beginning of that conversation. A wealthy woman who lost control over her body at exactly the moment she ought to have had the most say.

As you take one last look at the museum front, think of all the lives that have passed through its doors: ancient Egyptians, Victorian patients, Manchester heiresses who refused – or were refused – a burial.

title: River Gods in Stone: Henley Bridge
inscription: Henley’s handsome stone bridge is more than a crossing: it sits on the site of a medieval predecessor and carries carved keystones of the river deities Isis and Tamesis by pioneering female sculptor Anne Seymour Damer. You can stand beneath the arches that once framed barge traffic, regatta finishes and Victorian promenaders, and then look up to the same sculpted faces glaring down at 21st-century traffic.
lead_subject_bio:
You’re standing on Henley Bridge, on a strip of stone that has carried just about everything this town has ever cared about: grain and timber, gossip and fashions, Olympians and tourists. Beneath you the Thames slides steadily past, as if it has all the time in the world. Above, the cars and lorries that roar over your head are just the latest layer in a story that goes back to the Middle Ages.

Take a moment to look around you. Turn your body slowly: one way you see the long, straight regatta course stretching upstream, the meadows and boathouses; the other way, the curve of the river towards Marsh Mills and Wargrave. This view has been painted, photographed and filmed countless times, but most people never stop to think about the bridge itself.

This isn’t Henley’s first crossing. For centuries there was a wooden bridge here – patched, repaired, washed out in floods, rebuilt again. By the 1700s it was in such a state that travellers wrote complaining letters and merchants worried about both safety and reputation. A prosperous town with ambitions could not be fronted by a rickety, half-rotten bridge.

So the decision was taken: Henley would have a new, elegant stone bridge. Not just a functional crossing, but a statement. In the 1780s, masons, carpenters and labourers descended on the site. Imagine the river clogged with barges bringing stone, the air full of shouting and hammering. For a while, this was the town’s biggest construction project, and everyone had an opinion on how it should look.

Walk a little towards one of the central arches and look carefully at the underside. On the upstream and downstream faces, right at the centre, you’ll see carved stone heads – the river gods Isis and Tamesis – their faces emerging from swirling water and foliage. They were carved by Anne Seymour Damer, a highly unusual figure for her time: a female sculptor from the upper classes, more used to salons and politics than muddy river works.

Picture Damer overseeing her work here – a woman in a world of male builders and officials, chisel in hand, carving a personification of the river itself. The two heads represent the upper Thames (Isis) and the main river (Tamesis), meeting at Henley’s symbolic gateway. They’re decorative, but they also remind you who really has the last word in this town: the water.

Over the years, this bridge has seen everything. Regatta crowds surging across to the enclosures. Military convoys heading to and from war. Floods licking at the arches. Newlyweds posing for photos and teenagers dangling their legs over the parapet on warm evenings. It has carried more goodbyes and reunions than anyone could count.

Pause again and look down at the water beneath your feet. Imagine wooden barges loaded with timber grinding under these arches, or narrowboats queuing to get past the earlier wooden bridge. Imagine the nerves of a coach driver trying not to tip his horses over the edge. Today the traffic jams are mostly metal and rubber, but the basic human drama is the same: people trying to get from one side of the river to the other.

As you walk off the bridge, notice how it frames your view of Henley: the church tower ahead, the Angel on the Bridge pub tucked against its flank, the roofs stepping up the hill. This is more than a lump of stone. It’s a threshold. Every story on this tour – paupers in the workhouse, rowers on the reach, pop stars behind high walls – is connected by this crossing. You’re not just walking over a bridge; you’re stepping into the town’s main doorway.

title: Star-Struck Ales at The Angel on the Bridge
inscription: This Grade II pub perched virtually in the river began life in the early 18th century and is now one of the most photographed pubs in England. Inside, brass plates mark where Grace Kelly and music-hall star Max Miller once stood at the bar, adding a touch of showbusiness to its long history as a boatmen’s, regatta-goers’ and locals’ haunt.
lead_subject_bio:
You’re standing outside a pub that looks as if it’s trying to float away. The Angel on the Bridge perches so close to the Thames that at high water it seems to dip its toes into the river. If Henley Bridge is the town’s stone gateway, this is its riverside living room.

Take a moment to look around you. See how the building leans over the water, how the terrace gives you a front-row seat on the boats sliding underneath the bridge. This has always been prime real estate: the place to watch who’s coming and going.

The Angel dates back to the early 1700s, a time when the road outside would have been noisy with carts and stagecoaches and the river below packed with barges. Inside, imagine low ceilings stained brown from centuries of pipe smoke, horse harnesses creaking in the yard, bargemen nursing pints before pushing off into the dark.

If you step inside later, see if you can spot any old beams or awkward corners that betray the pub’s age. These walls have overheard countless heated arguments, flirtations and business deals. In regatta week, they’ve seen fortunes won and lost in side bets on races, and scores settled after too many celebratory drinks.

Over time, the clientele changed. As Henley Royal Regatta grew in prestige, so did the people flocking to this doorway. Instead of bargees and carriers, you’d find gentlemen rowers in blazers, ladies in fine dresses, bookmakers, journalists, and eventually film stars and royalty. Local lore says that Grace Kelly once stood at this bar. Comedian Max Miller is linked with the place too. Whether or not every story is perfectly accurate, the brass plaques and old photos inside show how proud the pub is of its famous visitors.

Stand on the terrace and look upriver. In regatta week this view becomes a riot of colour – striped blazers, fluttering flags, grandstands packed with spectators. The Angel is the perfect spot to half-watch the races and half-watch each other. For some people, this side of the river is more about being seen than seeing the rowing.

But underneath the glamour, it’s still a local pub. Away from the regatta, you’ll find dog walkers, regulars discussing council decisions, couples sharing a quiet drink by the windows. Staff deal with floods as well as festival weeks, with winter slow nights as well as summer mayhem.

Now look back at the bridge and the church tower beyond. This little triangle – bridge, pub, church – compresses centuries of Henley life into a single view: work and worship, trade and pleasure. The Angel on the Bridge has seen the town shift from river commerce to leisure resort, from horse-drawn deliveries to ride-share drop-offs, but the essentials haven’t changed much. People still come here to lean on a bar, gaze at the water, and say the things they might not say at home.

When you move on, imagine that every time someone has raised a glass here – in grief, in celebration, in reckless high spirits – that emotion has soaked into the floorboards. For the length of a drink, the Angel is where Henley’s public and private lives meet.

title: St Mary’s Tower & the Phillimore Fountain
inscription: In the shadow of St Mary’s medieval tower, a richly carved Victorian drinking fountain quietly tells a second story: how Henley used water, light and stone to honour a beloved rector and care for its thirsty townsfolk.
lead_subject_bio:
You’re standing at the gate of St Mary’s Church, with the tower rising above you and Hart Street running just behind your shoulder. For centuries, this square block of stone has been Henley’s exclamation mark – the point the whole town seems to pivot around.

Step through the lychgate and look around you. To one side, gravestones tilt at odd angles, their inscriptions fading back into the stone. To another, the brick line of the almshouses runs along the churchyard edge. And right out by the pavement, facing the road, there’s something else: an ornate stone structure with little columns, carved panels and, once upon a time, four lamps.

That isn’t a random bit of gothic decoration. It’s the Phillimore Fountain, Henley’s Victorian drinking fountain and one of the town’s most-loved landmarks.

First, though, the church. St Mary’s has been here in one form or another since the Middle Ages. Every big moment in Henley life has passed through these doors. Babies carried in for baptism, brides and grooms stepping out into the sunlight to the sound of bells, coffin lids glinting as they’re shouldered towards the open earth of the churchyard.

If you glance up at the tower you can still see the lines of different building campaigns: older stone patched with newer repairs, windows that have been altered as tastes changed. Imagine the bells being hauled up into place centuries ago, ropes led down into the ringing chamber, ringers practising changes that would spill out across the river and meadows.

Now, turn back towards Hart Street and walk over to the stone monument on the pavement. Look closely at it: the canopied top, the basins, the inscriptions. This is the Phillimore Fountain, erected in 1885 to honour the Reverend Greville Phillimore, who served as rector here for sixteen years.

Originally, this fountain didn’t stand here. It was put up in the Market Place, right in front of the Town Hall, as the town’s main civic monument. It replaced an older stone obelisk that had stood there since the late 1700s – a mile-marker and symbol of civic pride that listed the distances to Reading, Oxford and London.

For a while, the new fountain was the centre of things. Clean drinking water flowed from its spouts. People met here, gossiped here, and, according to local accounts, street sellers of lavender and other small goods clustered around its base beneath the glow of four lamps. It was a temperance-friendly alternative to the pubs: water instead of beer, philanthropy instead of profit.

But the town’s traffic patterns changed. Carts and then motor vehicles squeezed through the Market Place; the fountain became more obstacle than asset. In 1903, it was carefully taken down and moved here, beside the church where you’re standing now. The older obelisk, displaced first by the fountain, would eventually make its own journey down to the riverbank at Mill Meadows – where it stands today as a separate stop on your walk.

So what you’re looking at is a travelling monument that’s finally found a home. A Victorian love-letter to a well-regarded rector, built at the crossroads, then resettled at the church whose community paid for it.

Imagine this corner a hundred and twenty years ago. Look along Hart Street in your mind’s eye: fewer cars, more boots and cartwheels. People lining up at the fountain to fill jugs or cups. Children daring each other to dart through the falling water. Street vendors hovering just close enough to catch the trade, but not so close that the constable moves them on.

Today, the fountain has had another life breathed into it. In recent years the town has worked on restoring it, not just as a static monument but as a working water point again – somewhere you can refill a bottle instead of buying another single-use plastic one. Victorian worries about public health and clean water have quietly met 21st-century worries about waste and pollution.

Step back a little, so you can see the tower, the gravestones, the almshouses and the fountain all in one frame. In a few metres of ground, you’ve got Henley’s spiritual centre, its historic charity housing, and a memorial that once supplied both respectability and actual drinking water.

Then, as you turn to leave, listen for the bells if they’re ringing, and glance once more at the fountain’s inscription. One rector’s name is carved in stone, but hundreds of anonymous hands have cupped water here – and thousands of lives have passed through this patch of ground on their way to baptisms, weddings, funerals and ordinary Sundays.

When you carry on towards the river and eventually meet the stone obelisk at Mill Meadows, you’ll have the second half of this story: how a town’s monuments move around as its needs and fashions change, while the church at their centre quietly stays put.

title: From Chantry Priests to Picture-Perfect Cottage: Chantry House
inscription: Chantry House is one of Henley’s oldest dwellings, built for priests serving the adjacent church and now a picturesque timbered house overlooking the river. A recent restoration uncovered layers of alteration, offering a way to talk about medieval religion, Reformation upheavals, Georgian gentrification and modern conservation, all in one crooked building.
lead_subject_bio:
Just a few steps from the church, you come to a building that looks like it’s been pulled straight from a storybook: low, timber-framed, slightly crooked, with its upper floor jutting over the street. This is Chantry House, and beneath its pretty exterior lies a story of fear, faith and reinvention.

Pause and look closely at the front of the building. The dark beams, the lighter infill, the way windows have been punched through and enlarged over time – all of these are clues. When this house was built in the 1400s, it was probably home to priests whose job was to say masses for the souls of the dead. Wealthy benefactors left money to fund these “chantries”, hoping to speed their way through purgatory. Paying for prayers was a kind of spiritual insurance policy.

Imagine the life of those chantry priests. They would have moved back and forth between this house and St Mary’s, saying mass after mass for people they may never have met in life. Their work was invisible, repetitive, and absolutely central to medieval ideas about salvation.

Then the 1500s arrived, and with them, the Reformation. Henry VIII broke with Rome, and his son Edward VI’s government took aim at chantries.
